abstract: If we could cut the price of crude in half, Iran’s puppets would think three times about launching wars with Israel that might ravage Lebanon again.
snippet: If we could cut the price of crude in half, Iran’s puppets would think three times about launching wars with Israel that might ravage Lebanon again.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure yet who’s the winner in the war between Hezbollah and Israel, but I know who’s the big loser: Iran’s taxpayers. What a bunch of suckers.

lead_paragraph: PIRAEUS, Greece, Aug. 17 — The United Nations Environment Program on Thursday pledged 50 million euros, about $64 million, to help clean up and contain a major Mediterranean oil spill caused by the conflict in Lebanon.

abstract: The United Nations Environment Program on Thursday pledged 50 million euros, about $64 million, to help clean up and contain a major Mediterranean oil spill caused by the conflict in Lebanon.     The 87-mile-long slick, described by experts as the worst environmental disaster in Lebanese history, stained Lebanon's shores after Israeli warplanes bombed an oil storage depot at Jiyeh, about 19 miles south of Beirut, on July 13 and 15.

abstract: I'm not sure yet who's the winner in the war between Hezbollah and Israel, but I know who's the big loser: Iran's taxpayers. What a bunch of suckers.     Isn't it obvious? As soon as the reckless war he started was over, Hezbollah's leader, Hassan Nasrallah, declared that Hezbollah would begin paying out cash to the thousands of Lebanese families whose homes were destroyed. ''We will pay compensation, a certain amount of money for every family to rent for one year, plus buy furniture for those whose homes were totally destroyed,'' said Nasrallah. ''These number 15,000.''

abstract: Venezuela’s ties with Iran have become a defining element in its effort to curb American influence in developing countries.
snippet: Venezuela’s ties with Iran have become a defining element in its effort to curb American influence in developing countries.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 20 — Venezuela has long cultivated ties with Middle Eastern governments, finding common ground in trying to keep oil prices high, but its recent engagement of Iran has become a defining element in its effort to build an alliance to curb American influence in developing countries.

abstract: Venezuela has long cultivated ties with Middle Eastern governments, finding common ground in trying to keep oil prices high, but its recent engagement of Iran has become a defining element in its effort to build an alliance to curb American influence in developing countries.     In a visit late last month to Tehran by President Hugo Chávez and his oil minister, Rafael Ramírez, the two countries agreed to produce jointly nearly a dozen products, including crude oil and medicines. In a further sign that their ties have taken on a new dimension, the two countries are speaking in a more unified voice in their criticism of Israel and the United States.

abstract: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela reached an agreement this week with his counterpart in Angola, José Eduardo dos Santos, for the two countries to work jointly on oil and natural gas exploration projects. Though no formal ventures have been established, the agreement would allow the national oil company Petróleos de Venezuela to assist Sonangol, Angola’s state-controlled oil group, in its offshore exploration efforts. Mr. Chávez has been trying to forge stronger political ties with West African nations through energy agreements and contracts to buy exports like cotton, in efforts to enhance Venezuela’s influence in the region and expand membership of OPEC.

lead_paragraph: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela reached an agreement this week with his counterpart in Angola, José Eduardo dos Santos, for the two countries to work jointly on oil and natural gas exploration projects. Though no formal ventures have been established, the agreement would allow the national oil company Petróleos de Venezuela to assist Sonangol, Angola's state-controlled oil group, in its offshore exploration efforts. Mr. Chávez has been trying to forge stronger political ties with West African nations through energy agreements and contracts to buy exports like cotton, in efforts to enhance Venezuela's influence in the region and expand membership of OPEC. SIMON ROMERO (NYT)

abstract: Has our world become riskier in the past five years? That's almost a commonplace. But how much of that extra risk results from the terror attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon almost five years ago today? That's a question that is less likely to get a unanimous answer. It's difficult to remember that far back, but some of the trends we struggle with today were already established well before Sept. 11, 2001. Stock markets were shaky, the twin result of the bursting of the dot-com bubble in 2000 and the rumblings from Houston that one of the biggest players in financial markets, Enron, had been built on sand. Major economies, which sped forward on the adrenaline of the Internet, were beginning to slow down now that the easy gains in productivity and revenue had been booked. Threats to public health didn't start with 9/11; mad cow disease was claiming lives in Britain and Continental Europe, and hoof-and-mouth disease was decimating herds around the world. As for one of the greatest sources of financial insecurity - pensions - most national systems, and many corporate ones, were already beginning to groan under the weight of future liabilities. Has our world become riskier since Sept. 11? No question. But we were heading in that direction anyway.

abstract: Oil is down, but remains high as far as the eye can see
snippet: Oil is down, but remains high as far as the eye can see
lead_paragraph: Crude oil prices are falling today, and the spot contract, for October delivery, is quoted at $66.72 a barrel as this is being written. That is actually lower than the price a little over a year ago. On Sept. 1, 2005, the nearest contract, the October 2005 one, was trading for $69.47 a barrel, and the forecast for this October was $69.17. It has been a while since it was possible to have purchased an oil contract, held on for a year, and lost money.

abstract: VIENNA — Given the recent forecasts that oil prices might reach $100 a barrel, oil markets seem to have dodged a bullet this summer: prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel in the past month and gasoline has edged down, providing some relief after the Labor Day weekend in the United States.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Given the recent forecasts that oil prices might reach $100 a barrel, oil markets seem to have dodged a bullet this summer: prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel in the past month and gasoline has edged down, providing some relief after the Labor Day weekend in the United States.

abstract: As OPEC ministers prepare to meet Monday, they are wondering not how high oil prices will rise, but how far they may drop.
snippet: As OPEC ministers prepare to meet Monday, they are wondering not how high oil prices will rise, but how far they may drop.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA, Sept. 10 — What a difference a few weeks can make. As OPEC ministers prepare to meet here Monday, the question on their minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but how far they may drop.

abstract: The decision could lead to a further decline in oil prices, which have dropped more than $11 a barrel from their July peaks.
snippet: The decision could lead to a further decline in oil prices, which have dropped more than $11 a barrel from their July peaks.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA, Sept. 11 — OPEC said today that it would keep producing oil at current levels even though demand is slowing and inventories are growing — a decision that would seem to set the scene for further declines in oil prices, which have already fallen by more than $11 a barrel from their July peaks.

abstract: STEADY STREAM OPEC will meet in Vienna, and it is expected to keep its oil output quota unchanged at 28 million barrels a day. The price of crude oil has dipped a bit from recent record highs, but probably not enough for OPEC to curtail production, a move that would most likely anger many nations. (Monday.).

abstract: STEADY STREAM -- OPEC will meet in Vienna, and it is expected to keep its oil output quota unchanged at 28 million barrels a day. The price of crude oil has dipped a bit from recent record highs, but probably not enough for OPEC to curtail production, a move that would most likely anger many nations. (Monday.)    WHERE THERE'S SMOKE -- Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn will decide whether to certify as a class action a lawsuit contending that tobacco companies defrauded consumers with claims about ''light'' cigarettes. (Wednesday.) Lawyers for plaintiffs say their clients were duped into believing that the cigarettes were healthier than regular ones. Judge Weinstein previously tried to organize a single high-stakes trial over the harms of cigarettes, but was rebuffed by an appellate panel.    MORE CUTS AT FORD -- The board of the Ford Motor Company will meet, and an announcement is expected soon afterward on additional cost-cutting as part of a turnaround plan. (Thursday.) Ford is already in the process of closing 14 plants and cutting 30,000 jobs under its Way Forward restructuring program, and the new plan is expected to widen the effort. Last week William Clay Ford Jr., the great-grandson of the company's founder, hired an outsider, Alan R. Mulally, formerly of Boeing, as chief executive and president.    ECONOMIC INDICATORS -- The release of the Consumer Price Index for August will provide an updated snapshot of inflation, with implications for the Federal Open Market Committee's decision on interest rates later this month. (Monday.) Other reports: the trade deficit for July (Tuesday); retail sales for August, import prices for August and business inventories for July (Thursday); and industrial production and capacity utilization for August along with the first reading of the University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).    EARNINGS HERE AND THERE -- A few companies -- most notably some big Wall Street companies -- will report results this week. They include: Campbell Soup (Monday); Best Buy, Goldman Sachs and the Kroger Company (Tuesday); Lehman Brothers and Navistar International (Wednesday); and Adobe Systems, Bear Stearns and Pier 1 Imports (Thursday).

abstract: INTERNATIONAL A3-9    Bombing in Afghanistan Kills Provincial Governor  Muhammad Hakim Taniwal, governor of Paktia Province in Afghanistan and a close friend of President Hamid Karzai, was killed along with two staff members by a suicide bomber as they drove away from the president's office, government officials said. A1    Shiites Push New Legislation  A dispute in the Iraqi Parliament peaked as a large Shiite faction continued to fight for quick approval of legislation that would give provinces the authority to create autonomous states. Sunni lawmakers and others in opposition refused to attend the session, warning that the plan could undermine the country's unity government.  A8    Progress in Iran Sanction Talks  Representatives of Iran and the European Union said that they had made progress toward a compromise to avert possible United Nations sanctions over Iran's nuclear program and that they would meet again soon. A9    Blair and Abbas Hold Talks  The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, met with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain to discuss forming a Palestinian unity government that would seek to win international acceptance and end the isolation of the current Hamas-led government. A9    China Imposes News Limits  Under new rules, the state-run New China News Agency said it would control foreign news reports, photographs and graphics entering China. The agency announced that it would censor content that ''endangers national security.'' A3    Sri Lankan Rebel Line Breached  At least 28 soldiers were killed and more than 100 wounded as the Sri Lankan Army pushed across Tamil Tiger rebel front lines in the north, the military said. Independent verification was not possible; each side routinely plays down casualties. A8    NATIONAL A10-17    Heated Arizona Primary Draws National Attention  Arizona's Eighth Congressional District is a swing district and one of a handful nationwide that Democrats believe they can capture to reclaim the House. Ten candidates are battling to represent the district in Arizona, a fast-growing state that is not as conservative as it used to be.  A10    Medicare Costs to Increase  Higher-income people will have to pay higher Medicare premiums than other beneficiaries next year, as the government takes a step to help the financially ailing program remain viable over the long term.  A10    Immigration Protests Shrink  In Washington, Los Angeles, Phoenix and Batavia, Ill., immigrant demonstrations drew much smaller crowds than expected. Political analysts, policy makers and immigrants alike are questioning the staying power of the immigrant rights movement.  A11    Cheney on the Insurgency  In a television interview, Vice President Dick Cheney backed away from his insistence last year that the insurgency in Iraq was in its ''last throes,'' but said even if he had known in 2003 that his claims that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction were mistaken, ''we'd do exactly the same thing.'' A12    Shuttle Safely in Orbit  The space shuttle Atlantis appears to have made the jump into orbit without any damage to its heat shield, mission officials said. The mission will resume construction of the International Space Station.  A17    Executive's Fate Unresolved  A Hewlett-Packard board meeting ended with no decision on whether the chairwoman of the company would be asked to resign over her role in an investigation.  A17    At the heart of the Hewlett-Packard controversy is a technique called pretexting -- obtaining someone's calling records under a pretext, like pretending to be a customer.  C1    NEW YORK/REGION B1-5    Bush Visits Ground Zero On Eve of Anniversary  Vowing he was ''never going to forget the lessons of that day,'' President Bush paid tribute to the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attack, laying a wreath at ground zero, attending a prayer service at St. Paul's Chapel and making a few other stops with his wife, Laura. The ceremonies ushered in what will be a solemn day of remembrance, here and around the country as the official commemoration of the fifth anniversary of the attacks.  A1    Newark's Financial Crunch  Mayor Cory A. Booker's grand dreams for a safer, cleaner and more prosperous Newark are colliding with the reality of the city's troubled finances. Having won the election with ambitious promises, Mr. Booker is instead being forced to reduce services and raise taxes.  B1    Hope Fades for Democrats  In a year when Democrats hope to take control of the House of Representatives, New York would appear to be fertile ground for toppling Republican incumbents. But that goal now seems increasingly remote.  A1    SPORTSMONDAY D1-9    Federer Wins U.S. Open  Roger Federer defeated Andy Roddick in the championship game of the United States Open. Federer was 27-1 in the four Grand Slam events this season, winning the Australian Open, Wimbledon and now the United States Open, and it was one more measure of his dominance that no man in this tournament was able to win more than one set against him. D1    OBITUARIES B6    King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV  The king of Tonga, a Polynesian archipelago of 150 islands with 100,000 subjects and the last reigning monarch in the Pacific, he was 88. B6    BUSINESS DAY C1-10    OPEC Price Concerns  OPEC ministers are preparing to meet in Vienna, and the question on their minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but how far they might drop. Crude oil prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel, driving down the retail price of gasoline and providing some relief for consumers.  C1    Apple's Next Campaign  Apple will hold another of Steven P. Jobs's marketing events to unveil what is expected to be his next campaign: to transform the distribution of movies as thoroughly as he has revolutionized the recording industry with iTunes.  C1    Firms Near Deal in Buyout  A consortium of investment firms were near a deal to acquire Freescale Semiconductor, a former unit of Motorola, for more than $16 billion, according to people briefed on the negotiations. The deal, if completed, would be the largest leveraged buyout in the technology sector, surpassing the $11.3 billion sale of SunGard Data Systems last year. A17    Business Digest C2    EDITORIAL A18-19    Editorials: 9/11/06; activism is in the eye of the ideologist; three weeks to save Darfur; denying the vote.    Column: Paul Krugman.    Bridge E3  Crossword E2  Metro Diary B2  TV Listings E8  Weather D10

abstract: VIENNA — OPEC met on Monday against the backdrop of a $13 fall in the price of a barrel of oil since mid-July, but ministers said they were unlikely to tamper with output ahead of the peak winter demand season and with supply worries ever present.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — OPEC met on Monday against the backdrop of a $13 fall in the price of a barrel of oil since mid-July, but ministers said they were unlikely to tamper with output ahead of the peak winter demand season and with supply worries ever present.

abstract: What a difference a few weeks can make. As OPEC ministers prepare to meet here Monday, the question on their minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but how far they may drop.     Crude oil prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel in the last month, driving down the retail price of gasoline and providing some relief for consumers. While energy prices remain high, they have not risen to the heights that many analysts had feared, in part because of a light hurricane season this summer, the cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah, and the fact that the United Nations has not imposed sanctions on Iran.
snippet: What a difference a few weeks can make. As OPEC ministers prepare to meet here Monday, the question on their minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but how far they may drop.     Crude oil prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel in the last...
lead_paragraph: VIENNA, Sept. 10 - What a difference a few weeks can make. As OPEC ministers prepare to meet here Monday, the question on their minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but how far they may drop.

abstract: CRUNCH TIME AT ABC -- On Wednesday, the ''Today'' show on NBC -- the ratings leader in morning TV -- will introduce a new co-host, Meredith Vieira, who is succeeding Katie Couric. At ABC's ''Good Morning America'' the senior executive producer, Jim Murphy, will use the transition at ''Today'' to try wooing enough people over to ABC to erase what was a nearly 900,000-viewer advantage. Mr. Murphy is also trying to make sure that loyal viewers do not abandon ''Good Morning America'' as it goes through a major transition of its own: the departure of Charles Gibson. [Page C1.]    CARTOONS ON THE CELLPHONE -- ''Lil' Bush,'' a cartoon show about the adventures of a grade-school version of President Bush and his pals made its debut on Amp'd cellphones on Sept. 1. Six five-minute episodes are to be released every week for six weeks, and each is to be available on demand afterward. The series is another example of cellphone service companies looking to attract subscribers -- and draw more money out of existing ones -- with original content, especially video. [C5.]    SHOWTIME AT APPLE -- On Tuesday, Apple will hold another of Steven P. Jobs's marketing events to unveil what is expected to be his next campaign: to transform the distribution of movies as thoroughly as he has revolutionized the recording industry with iTunes. [C1.]    GAMES FOR CASUAL PLAYERS -- Video game makers are starting to go after the casual or coffee-break gamer, who indulges in short-term play and not necessarily of the action-packed genre. [C7.]    THE MARKETING OF 9/11 -- Marketers and the news media, acutely aware of the sensitivities surrounding Sept. 11, 2001, are still trying to determine where the fine line lies between commemoration and exploitation. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C8.]    SHOPPING AND SOCIALIZING -- Several sites on the Internet -- like ThisNext.com, Kaboodle.com, Wists.com and StyleHive.com -- are spearheading a new category of e-commerce called social shopping that tries to combine two favorite online activities: shopping and social networking. Like MySpace, the sites are designed for browsing and blogging, with some shopping-related technology twists included. ''Online shopping is more accurately described as purchasing, because it's so directed and goal-specific,'' said Gordon Gould, ThisNext's chief executive, left. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C6.]    THE PRETEXT MASQUERADE -- At the heart of the controversy swirling around Hewlett-Packard is the technique known as pretexting -- obtaining the calling records of people under a pretext, like masquerading as a customer. The shady subculture of pretexting has been getting renewed attention since it came to light last week that a subcontractor for an investigative firm working for H.P. used pretexting to obtain the call records of company directors and reporters. [C1.]    FOR OPEC, PRICE CONCERNS -- What a difference a few weeks can make. As OPEC ministers prepare to meet today, the major question on delegates' minds is not how high oil prices will rise, but just how far they might drop. Crude oil prices have fallen more than $10 a barrel in the last month, driving down the retail price of gasoline and providing some relief for consumers. [C1.]    REGIONAL NEWS AND LAYOFFS -- On Thursday, The Dallas Morning News is expected to announce that more than 100 newsroom staffers have accepted buyout packages, shrinking the size of the staff by slightly less than 20 percent. As a result, what was once a newspaper with national reach will focus mainly on local and regional news. [C4.]    RESTRUCTURING IN ITALY -- Telecom Italia, the telecommunications company, said yesterday that its board would discuss the restructuring of its mobile and fixed-line phone operations today, a move that may presage the sale of all or part of its mobile arm, TIM. [C4.]

abstract: OPEC hinted that it was ready to cut production, as some delegates voiced concerns over a possible plunge in prices.
snippet: OPEC hinted that it was ready to cut production, as some delegates voiced concerns over a possible plunge in prices.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA, Sept. 11 — OPEC said on Monday that it would keep its current production levels unchanged for the time being but hinted that it was ready to cut production, as some delegates voiced concerns that high oil inventories and slowing demand might ignite a plunge in prices.

abstract: OPEC decides to keep current production levels unchanged but hints it is ready to cut production, as some delegates voice concerns that high inventories and slowing demand might spur price plunge; decision comes as oil supplies remain ample despite losses from BP operations in Alaska, chronic shortages in Iraq and attacks on Nigerian export terminals; photo (M)

abstract: WASHINGTON — High oil import prices and a strong demand for foreign goods ranging from cars to computers helped push the U.S. trade deficit to a record $68 billion in July, a government report showed Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — High oil import prices and a strong demand for foreign goods ranging from cars to computers helped push the U.S. trade deficit to a record $68 billion in July, a government report showed Tuesday.

abstract: VIENNA — A slowing U.S. housing market and the possibility of a major oil supply disruption are two of the biggest risks to economies worldwide, the head of the International Monetary Fund, Rodrigo Rato, said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — A slowing U.S. housing market and the possibility of a major oil supply disruption are two of the biggest risks to economies worldwide, the head of the International Monetary Fund, Rodrigo Rato, said Tuesday.

abstract: UPHEAVAL AT BRISTOL-MYERS -- A court-approved overseer has recommended that the board of Bristol-Myers Squibb fire its chief executive, Peter R. Dolan, for the company's recent handling of a patent dispute that has led to a criminal investigation, according to a participant in a meeting last evening where the recommendation was made. [Page C1.]    PRESSURE ON HEWLETT-PACKARD -- Hewlett-Packard found itself under increased legal and political scrutiny over the investigative tactics it used against its directors, and the company's board spent a second day trying to find a way out of the crisis. [C1.]    $1 BILLION OIL WINDFALL POSSIBLE -- A group of oil companies led by Chevron, which announced last week that they had discovered a giant new oil field in the Gulf of Mexico, could avoid more than $1 billion in royalty payments to the federal government for that oil. Chevron's shares fell along with those of other oil companies after news on oil production from OPEC. [C1.]    VYING FOR FREESCALE -- Two private equity groups are now competing to acquire Freescale Semiconductor, the microchip maker, for more than $16 billion, people involved in the negotiations said. [C1.]    RENEWED INTEREST IN UNIVISION -- A consortium of investors led by Grupo Televisa is considering a plan to mount a $13 billion bid for Univision Communications, the Spanish-language media company, after losing an auction for it this summer, executives involved in the negotiations said. [C4.]    OPEC KEEPS OUTPUT STEADY -- OPEC said that it would keep its current production levels unchanged for the time being but hinted that it was ready to cut production, as some delegates voiced concerns that high oil inventories and slowing demand might ignite a plunge in prices. [C3.]    CHICAGO WAGE PLAN VETOED -- Mayor Richard M. Daley vetoed a City Council plan to make Chicago the first city in the nation to single out ''big box'' retailers like Wal-Mart and Home Depot for wage minimums for their workers. [A14.]    DELL TO DELAY RESULTS -- Dell said that it was delaying the filing of its second-quarter financial report as it worked to comply with a widening investigation into its accounting practices. [C3.]    RUSSIA BUYS STAKE IN EADS -- European Aeronautic Defense and Space, the French-German military contractor, confirmed that a bank owned by the Russian government had acquired more than 5 percent of the company, the first time that a Russian institution had acquired a significant holding in a Western plane maker. [C7.]    ABOUT-FACE AT TELECOM ITALIA -- Telecom Italia, in a reversal of a recent and expensive consolidation, announced plans to spin off its fixed-line and mobile phone businesses into two companies. Its chairman also said that he would consider offers to sell the mobile phone business. [C6.]    TELUS CHANGES STRUCTURE -- Telus, one of the largest telecommunications companies in Canada, said that it would abandon its current stock ownership in favor of an income trust. [C3.]    INDIA AS AUTOMAKER -- India's quest to be a leading carmaker has received a vigorous boost, with a parade of global companies unfurling plans to assemble cars there for domestic consumption and export. [C5.]    CHINA TRADE SURPLUS GROWS -- China's trade surplus with the world ballooned last month to $18.8 billion as exports soared, setting a fourth consecutive monthly record, according to preliminary figures. The surplus gives fresh ammunition to requests by American officials that China intervene less in currency trading to hold down the value of the yuan. Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., above, is scheduled to visit Beijing late next week in his first visit to China since he took office in July. [C6.]    NEW WAYS TO TREAT STUTTERING -- Scientists are making progress on new medical treatments for stuttering, including a drug by Indevus Pharmaceuticals. [F1.]    THE FLU AND AIR TRAVEL -- Airline travel has a significant effect on the spread of influenza, a new study reports, raising the question of whether flight restrictions may be helpful in controlling a pandemic. [F9.]    NEW MONOPOLY NAMES -- An updated edition of Monopoly will include tokens that are styled after name-brand products. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C3.]    ONLINE    DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    ASK THE NEWSROOM -- Richard L. Berke, assistant managing editor for news, is answering readers' questions at nytimes.com/business.    FIRST LOOK -- A showcase for new features and services that are developing at NYTimes.com can be found at nytimes.com/technology.

abstract: Any time that OPEC got a little too overzealous in pushing up oil prices back in the 1970's, the legendary Saudi oil minister Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani was fond of telling his colleagues: Remember, the Stone Age didn't end because we ran out of stones.     What he meant was that the Stone Age ended because people invented alternative tools. The oil age is also not going to end because we run out of oil. It will end because the price of oil goes so high that people invent alternatives. Mr. Yamani was warning his colleagues not to get too greedy and stimulate those alternatives.

lead_paragraph: If someone says “oil producer,” what country pops to mind? Chances are, the answer will be Saudi Arabia. It’s a common assumption in any discussion of the great global oil game that Americans drive around with abandon — through swamps, across fields of boulders, up dizzying cliffs — in their mighty sport utility vehicles and that the Saudis, above all others, just keep stuffing oil cash into their pockets.

lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

abstract: OPEC sent energy markets on a roller coaster this past week, saying it was considering cutting output as some of the group's members indicated that they were becoming increasingly nervous about slumping prices. Oil ministers of the group of oil producing countries may hold a special meeting in the coming weeks to endorse lower output levels, according to the Nigerian oil minister, Edmund Daukoru. But Daukoru, who is OPEC's current president, did not confirm accounts that it was on the verge of endorsing an immediate cut of a million barrels a day. Oil prices have dropped more than 20 percent from their summer high as there were few storms this hurricane season and commercial inventories filled up. As a group, OPEC has not reduced production since early 2005, and OPEC producers have been notably undisciplined in the past about sticking to agreements to reduce production; whether they can act in concert now remains in doubt. "They have a chance to impact oil stocks before the winter starts," Roger Diwan, a managing director at PFC Energy, a consulting firm in Washington, told Jad Mouawad of The New York Times. "They are putting fear back into the market."
lead_paragraph: OPEC sent energy markets on a roller coaster this past week, saying it was considering cutting output as some of the group's members indicated that they were becoming increasingly nervous about slumping prices. But Daukoru, who is OPEC's current president, did not confirm accounts that it was on the verge of endorsing an immediate cut of a million barrels a day. Oil prices have dropped more than 20 percent from their summer high as there were few storms this hurricane season and commercial inventories filled up. As a group, OPEC has not reduced production since early 2005, and OPEC producers have been notably undisciplined in the past about sticking to agreements to reduce production; whether they can act in concert now remains in doubt. "They have a chance to impact oil stocks before the winter starts," Roger Diwan, a managing director at PFC Energy, a consulting firm in Washington, told Jad Mouawad of The New York Times. "They are putting fear back into the market."

abstract: RUSSIA AS ENVIRONMENTALIST -- Now that the Russian government is seeking to stall huge oil projects in eastern Siberia by Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil, it has suddenly discovered its inner environmentalist. [Page C1.]    OPEC MAY CUT OUTPUT -- The OPEC oil cartel sent energy markets on a roller coaster, saying it was considering cutting output. Some of the group's members indicated they were worried about slumping prices. [C10.]    DEAL FOR CANADIAN OIL SANDS -- ConocoPhillips said it would combine ownership of two of its refineries in Texas with Canadian oil sands properties controlled by the oil and gas producer EnCana. [C10.]    RYANAIR MAKES HOSTILE BID -- Ryanair, the low-fare airline based in Ireland, started a hostile bid for a rival, Aer Lingus, in a move that could bring the budget carrier American cities served by Aer Lingus. Ryanair's chief, Michael O'Leary, left, has been contemptuous of Aer Lingus's management. [C7.]    HEDGE FUND AS CAMPAIGN CHEST -- Two years ago, Andrew M. Cuomo, a candidate for attorney general of New York, put $750,000 -- more than half of his campaign treasury -- into a hedge fund. The investment turned out to be all upside, with one-year returns of nearly 20 percent. [A1.]    A CAT FOR PEOPLE WITH ALLERGIES -- Allerca, a California biotech company says it is ready to deliver the Holy Grail of the $35 billion pet industry: a hypoallergenic cat. The first kittens will be delivered early next year, at a cost of $4,000 each. [A14.]    A LAND DEAL TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE -- Federal investigators are trying to sort out the suspicious purchase and resale of 184 homes in a down-and-out neighborhood in Indianapolis. The company that bought the mortgages says it was the victim of a fraud. [C1.]    PUBLISHER IS FORCED OUT -- Jeffrey M. Johnson, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times, was forced out after refusing to make job cuts demanded by his corporate bosses at the Tribune Company. Dean Baquet, the paper's editor, who had also refused to make the job cuts, kept his job. [C1.]    FORD LOSING INTEREST IN ALLIANCE -- Carlos Ghosn, who heads Nissan of Japan and Renault of France, has made it clear that he wants a North American alliance. But in the aftermath of failed talks with G.M., his time may be past. [C3.]    AVOIDING THE CROWDED FLIGHTS -- If you want an empty seat beside you on your next flight, just schedule a trip to someplace like Kingman, Ariz.; Brookings, S.D.; or Pueblo, Colo. [A1.]    FORMER CHAIRWOMAN IN COURT -- Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, appeared in court in San Jose, Calif., after being charged in connection with a corporate spying operation. She was booked on four felony charges and agreed to return to court for an arraignment hearing. [C3.]    NEW BOOK ON H.P. -- Carleton S. Fiorina, the chairwoman of Hewlett Packard before she was fired in 2005, deserves plenty of credit for H.P.'s recent recovery. Or so she says, in her new book, ''Tough Choices.'' [C3.]    NO ACTION AGAINST PEQUOT -- The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission will not recommend an enforcement action against Pequot Capital Management or its employees relating to an insider trading investigation, according to a letter from the fund to its clients. [C1.]    RETAIL SALES UP -- Sales at retailers rose more in September than analysts estimated because of falling gas prices, brightening prospects for the holiday season. But Wal-Mart trailed rivals like Federated, J. C. Penney, Gap and Target. [C2.]    STOCKS GAIN AGAIN -- Stocks rose for a third day, extending the Dow Jones industrial average's record-breaking rally, helped by a rebound in energy and commodity companies. [C8.]    EUROPEAN BANK LIFTS RATES -- The European Central Bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.25 percent, citing a risk of higher inflation. It was the fifth increase since last December. [C4.]    COMPARING BLINDNESS DRUGS -- The National Institutes of Health said that it would sponsor a clinical trial comparing two Genentech drugs that have sharply different costs as a treatment for the leading cause of blindness in the elderly. [C3.]    ONLINE    SMALL BUSINESS -- The rapid expansion of Vince, a sportswear line, has caught no one by surprise, except perhaps its partners, all veterans of mainstream apparel manufacturing companies. A special report is at nytimes.com/business.    BUSINESS TRAVEL -- The new reality of business travel includes more unexpected destinations. A special report is at nytimes.com/business.    NETWORKING -- A special report exploring the proliferation of VoIP technology and other new wireless innovations is at nytimes.com/technology.    Business Briefing     Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    Wal-Mart said that it would expand a program offering generic drugs for $4 a prescription throughout Florida and that it might bring the program to other states before the end of the year. (REUTERS)    Some 15,000 members of the United Steelworkers union went on strike on Thursday at 16 plants owned by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. (REUTERS)    Starbucks said that it had set a new long-term goal to have 40,000 coffee stores worldwide, 10,000 more than its previous target and more than triple the current number. Starbucks also announced a deal to feature the music it sells in its stores on the Apple Computer iTunes Store.     The company said it expected to have more than 14,000 stores worldwide by the fall of 2007. There are currently about 12,000 Starbucks stores around the world. (AP)

It is the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, not the Organization of the Oil Producing Countries.

abstract: A consensus among OPEC members began to form over the weekend about cuts in oil production to help stem the recent decline in price, but the group's members have not yet agreed on how to share the reduced output.     While more of OPEC's members have lined up behind a proposal to pare the group's formal ceiling by one million barrels a day, significant hurdles remain before the cuts can be put in place. It would be the first time OPEC had cut its quotas in two years.

abstract: INTERNATIONAL A3-9    North Korea Announces Test of Nuclear Weapon  North Korea said that it had set off its first nuclear test -- just two days after the country was warned by the United Nations Security Council that the action could lead to severe consequences. American officials cautioned that they had not yet received any confirmation that the test had occurred.  A1    The North Korea nuclear test amounted to a major failure for China, which mounted one of its most extensive diplomatic efforts in years to find a negotiated solution to the North Korean nuclear crisis. The Chinese expressed their anger in unusually strong terms, saying the test was ''flagrant and brazen.''  A6    Tsunami Project Stalled  Construction of a road in Banda Aceh, Indonesia, meant as a good-will gesture from the American people to the survivors of the 2004 tsunami, has met with difficulty. Because of long negotiations to acquire right of way through residential and farm land, and through several hundred graves of religious significance, the project has not even started.  A8    Hints at Need for Iraq Change  James A. Baker III, the Republican co-chairman of a panel reassessing Iraq strategy for President Bush, said he expected that the panel would depart from Mr. Bush's repeated calls to ''stay the course,'' and he strongly suggested that the White House enter direct talks with countries it has so far kept at arms length, including Iran and Syria.  A1    American and Iraqi troops fought a fierce battle with militants in the city of Diwaniya, a stronghold of militia members loyal to radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, the American military said. The skirmish was the third serious clash between American or Iraqi soldiers against members of the Mahdi Army in Diwaniya in less than two months.  A8    Japan and China Mend Fences  China and Japan said they had made progress addressing their historical animosities and territorial differences as Shinzo Abe, the new Japanese prime minister, made his first trip to mend ties with Asian neighbors. President Hu Jintao of China, left, called Mr. Abe's visit a turning point for two Asian powers whose relations had sharply declined.  A3    Iran Opposition Cleric Seized  Ayatollah Mohammad Kazemeni Boroujerdi, a senior cleric who opposes clerical rule of Iran, was arrested after clashes with Iranian police officers, news agencies reported. The reports quoted officials as saying that some of the cleric's supporters were armed with knives and daggers and that the police used tear gas to disperse them.  A3    Transponder Not Recalled  The electronic device for broadcasting a plane's identity and altitude carried by the business jet that apparently collided with a Boeing 737 over the Amazon was not one of the potentially faulty ones ordered repaired by American safety officials, the manufacturer said.  A9    NATIONAL A10-15    Religious Employers Enjoy Legal Shield From Lawsuits  Legislators, judges and regulators have carved out or preserved safe havens that shield religious employers of all faiths from most employee lawsuits, from laws protecting pensions and providing unemployment benefits, and from laws that give employees the right to form unions to negotiate with their employers.  A1    Virginia Republicans Resolute  In dozens of interviews in southeastern Virginia, a swing state in tight races for the House and Senate, many conservative Christians said that rather than discourage them from going to the polls, the scandal surrounding Representative Mark Foley only reinforced their reasons to vote for their Republican incumbents.  A1    For all the contradictions and inconsistencies in the tale of Mark Foley, the investigation into how Republicans handled concerns about his conduct may hinge on what transpired in a private meeting that was convened in his office last year.  A12    Races Hinge on Local Economy  Michigan's political races for governor and the Senate are hinging nearly entirely on the struggling economy and the question of who is to blame for it. And in other Rust Belt states, including Ohio, Indiana and Pennsylvania, economic worries are playing a similar role, if a far more subtle one.  A10    Lawyer's Book Causes Trouble  Joyce Dudley, a deputy district attorney in Santa Barbara, published a crime novel. The novel concerns a rape case with echoes of a real one. An appeals court in Ventura, Calif., ruled that Ms. Dudley's novel had crossed an ethical line, and removed her from the case.  A10    Fight Over National Park Hunt  Representative Duncan Hunter, Republican of California, is fighting to preserve an agreement by the National Park Service to close 45,000 acres of parkland on Santa Rosa Island, Calif., to the public for hunting, August through December.  A15    Lettuce Recalled for E. Coli  Less than a week after the Food and Drug Administration lifted its warning on fresh spinach grown in the Salinas Valley, a popular brand of lettuce grown there was recalled over concerns about E. coli contamination. The lettuce does not appear to have caused any illnesses, the president of the grower said.  A10    Senator's Finances Questioned  For the past five years, Senator George Allen, Republican of Virginia, has failed to tell Congress about stock options he received for his work as a director of a high-tech company. Congressional rules require senators to disclose all deferred compensation, like stock options.  A13    NEW YORK/REGION B1-8    Despite Criticism at Home, Giuliani Retains Support  Rudolph W. Giuliani, former mayor of New York, is scheduled to make his first public appearance in two years in New Hampshire. Yet as Mr. Giuliani traverses the country, polls show he has emerged as a leading candidate for the Republican presidential primaries -- largely because of how he guided a wounded city in the weeks after 9/11.  B1    Cluster of Sex Offenders  A house where four sex offenders lived together as roommates has caused an uproar in Suffolk County, where one Suffolk County lawmaker has called for legislation to prevent groups of registered sex offenders from living together.  B1    A Mall of Knockoffs  In the last two years, the city has seized close to $50 million in counterfeit goods from the city's top haven for knockoff and phony goods, and shut down 15 buildings that it claimed were once occupied almost entirely by counterfeiters, but thousands of people still pack the area on weekends.  B1    SPORTSMONDAY D1-10    Steinbrenner Silent on Torre  George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, is fuming over the team's first-round elimination by the Detroit Tigers. He issued a blistering statement through his publicist but took no action on Joe Torre, his manager for the last 11 seasons.  D1    Ugly Finish at Talladega  Brian Vickers won the UAW-Ford 500 at Talladega Superspeedway, after pushing his teammate Jimmie Johnson's car into Dale Earnhardt Jr., on the backstretch of the last lap.  D9    ARTS E1-10    Unlikely Success at Book Fair  A book by the American author Jonathan Littell, ''Les Bienveillantes,'' has taken the Frankfurt fair, the world's largest booksellers' convention, by storm. Written in French, the novel features an unrepentant Nazi SS officer as the hero and could command $1 million, publishers say.  E1    OBITUARIES B9    David G. Salten  An innovative and influential educator who devised a desegregation plan for the New Rochelle, N.Y., school system and, as an expert witness in 1958, urged the immediate opening of the newly integrated schools in Little Rock, Ark., he was 93.  B9    BUSINESS DAY C1-12    Restructuring Airbus  Discussions over who would ultimately make decisions regarding the restructuring at Airbus continued over the weekend, and executives close to the talks said that the chief executive, M. Christian Streiff, could resign if he does not secure the autonomy that he wants.  C1    New Season on Network TV  The new network television season has three new shows that are giving early signs of being winners: ''Heroes'' on NBC, ''Jericho'' on CBS and ''Ugly Betty'' on ABC. But on the down side, several new shows have already been dropped.  C1    OPEC May Cut Production  A consensus among OPEC members began to form about cuts in oil production to help stem the decline in price, but the group's members have not yet agreed on how to share the reduced output.  C2    Business Digest C2    EDITORIAL A16-17    Editorials: Protecting a freedom to insult; the White House and Mr. Abramoff; looking over the wall.    Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman.    Bridge E8  Crossword E4  Metro Diary B2  TV Listings E9  Weather D4

abstract: THE NEW TV SEASON -- Three weeks into the new network television season, three new shows are giving early signs of being winners: ''Heroes'' on NBC, ''Jericho'' on CBS and ''Ugly Betty'' on ABC. And some scheduling moves have worked brilliantly, like ABC's shift of ''Grey's Anatomy,'' now television's hottest show'' to Thursday night. But on the down side for the networks, several new shows have already been dropped from schedules and many new series have wasted huge audiences from the hit shows that preceded them. [Page C1.]    A WARNING FOR STUDIOS -- Warner's recent tumble in the studio rankings is a cautionary tale for Hollywood. As the studios begin to shrink their slates and make fewer movies, they are increasing their reliance on the big, expensive extravaganzas. Sometimes they succeed, as ''Batman Begins'' and the ''Harry Potter'' movies have for Warner. But the lackluster results for Warner's blockbusters this summer show that the large tentpole features are not sure things, after all. And when they fail, they put more pressure on smaller films to open big. [C1.]    GUIDING NEW CONSUMERS -- Marketers of all sorts are being urged to give up the steering wheel to a new breed of consumers who want more control over the ways products are peddled to them. Exhortations to bring consumers into the tent dominated an advertising industry conference. Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C8.]    CONNECTING FAMILIES -- Genealogy sites have long helped their customers reconnect with long-dead ancestors. Now, in keeping with the social networking trend, some sites are trying to connect the living as well. Tim Sullivan, MyFamily's chief executive, left, said that changes at Ancestry.com, had spurred interaction between close and distant relatives by letting them more freely share information about their forebears and post old photos. Bob Tedeschi. E-Commerce Report. [C9.]    A SHIFT AT MICROSOFT -- At Microsoft, the effort to overhaul the Windows operating system was meant to offer a transformation to a new software foundation. But several ambitious initiatives failed to materialize in time, and the project started over from scratch three years ago. The result is more an evolutionary shift, focusing on visual modernization and ease of use. Still, the company is within a month of completing work on new versions of both Windows and Office. [C1.]    OPEC PRODUCTION CUTS -- A consensus among OPEC members began to form over the weekend about cuts in oil production to help stem the recent decline in price, but members have not yet agreed on how to share the reduced output. [C2.]    BROADER DIRECTORY SEARCHES -- Tellme Networks and Cingular Wireless are planning an enhanced 411 information service that will use Tellme's voice recognition technology to begin offering some Internet-style searches in addition to telephone directory information. The new Cingular service will permit subscribers to ask questions for a broader set of queries than traditional directory lookup. Information can be delivered as text-to-speech or as a simple text message delivered to the cellphone. [C8.]    NEW BOOK, LOST JOB -- On Tuesday, Joe Maguire, one of two editors in charge of markets coverage at Reuters, handed his bosses the galleys of his new book, ''Brainless: The Lies and Lunacy of Ann Coulter.'' On Wednesday, Mr. Maguire discovered he would have plenty of free time to promote his book, which comes out this week. Neither side in this dispute would say that he was fired. ''There was a difference of opinion about the approval I received to write this book,'' Mr. Maguire said. [C6.]    QUESTIONS ABOUT POLICY MEETING -- In his new book, ''State of Denial,'' Bob Woodward revealed the presence of journalists, including Fareed Zakaria, the editor of Newsweek International, left, at an otherwise secret meeting Nov. 29, 2001 to discuss Afghanistan and the Middle East in the aftermath of 9/11. The meeting, which included policy makers, Middle East experts and members of influential policy research organizations, was convened by Paul D. Wolfowitz, then the deputy secretary of defense, in an effort to produce a report for President Bush and his cabinet outlining a strategy for the region. Media Talk. [C6.]    TROUBLES AT AIRBUS -- Discussions over who will ultimately make decisions regarding the revamping at Airbus continued over the weekend, and executives close to the talks said Sunday that the chief executive, Christian Streiff, could resign as early as Monday if he did not secure the autonomy that he wanted. [C1.]    SALE OF BANK STAKE -- Istithmar PJSC, an investment company owned by Dubai's ruling Maktoum family, has acquired a stake of about $1 billion in the London bank Standard Chartered as it seeks to diversify income beyond oil in the United Arab Emirates. [C8.]

abstract: OPEC ministers have been debating for nearly a week how to put a brake on falling oil prices, which have dropped nearly 25 percent since their high in mid-July.
snippet: OPEC ministers have been debating for nearly a week how to put a brake on falling oil prices, which have dropped nearly 25 percent since their high in mid-July.
lead_paragraph: Once again, OPEC is finding that it is much easier to agree when prices rise than when they fall.

abstract: OPEC ministers are debating how to put brake on falling oil prices, which have dropped nearly 25 percent since their high in mid-July; OPEC's 11 members have found it hard to agree on how quickly to act and how production cuts should be shared, confusing markets; price of crude oil for November delivery drops 2.4 percent, to eight-month low of $58.52 per barrel in New York trading; Iran and Venezuela have called for special meeting in Vienna next week to endorse production cuts; others, like Kuwait and Algeria, have backed proposal but disagree on how to apportion cuts; Nigeria has resisted calls for meeting next week to avoid overshadowing OPEC's next scheduled meeting, to be held in Abuja, Nigeria, in December; Saudi Arabia, group's most influential member, has remained silent; Saudis are understood to support production cut, but OPEC watchers reason country, which accounts for third of OPEC's output, want to be discreet just weeks before midterm elections in US; photo (M)

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-16    Rice Says North Korea Faces Tougher Sanctions  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said the United States did not intend to attack North Korea, but she warned the North's leaders that they now risk sanctions ''unlike anything that they have faced before.''    A1    North Korea's claim that it had detonated a nuclear device rippled through American politics, as Senator John McCain sought to place the blame on former President Bill Clinton.    A1    South Korea and Japan, America's two major allies in the region, have grown increasingly apart in their attitudes and policies toward North Korea.    A8    600,000 KIlled, Iraq Study Says  A team of public health researchers have estimated that 600,000 civilians have died in violence across Iraq since the 2003 American invasion, a figure far higher than any other previous estimates of Iraqi deaths.    A16    Scores of bodies turned up in Baghdad and a series of bombs killed at least 24 people, indicating that the sectarian violence in the capital showed little sign of easing despite efforts by the American military and its Iraqi counterparts to quell it.    A16    A Laptop for Each Libyan Child  The government of Libya reached an agreement with One Laptop Per Child, an American group developing an inexpensive, educational laptop computer, with the goal of supplying machines to 1.2 million Libyan children by June of 2008.    A14    Pact Close in Mexican Strike  A violent standoff in the southern Mexico city of Oaxaca appeared headed for a peaceful end, as leaders of a group of striking teachers reached a tentative accord with the government.    A5    NATIONAL   A18-25    Disability Rates Are High Among Iraq War Veterans  Nearly one in five service members leaving the military after serving in Iraq and Afghanistan has been at least partially disabled, according to Veterans Administration documents obtained by a research group.    A18    Voting Rights Lawsuit  The Justice Department has chosen a town in eastern Mississippi for an unusual civil rights test: the first federal lawsuit against blacks for suppressing the voting rights of whites.    A18    Copper Company Accused  A bankrupt copper giant facing billions of dollars in pollution claims across the nation pretended for years to recycle metals while illegally burning hazardous wastes in a notorious El Paso smelter, according to newly released Environmental Protection Agency documents.    A18    Transcripts in School Killings  An hour after walking into a small Amish schoolhouse in Pennsylvania last week with an arsenal of guns and hardware, Charles C. Roberts IV told a 911 dispatcher in a calm, dispassionate voice that he took 10 girls hostage and wanted everyone off the property, according to a transcript of the conversation released.   A23    House Speaker Warns Staff  House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, said members of his staff should be fired ''if there was a cover-up'' in how they handled complaints about Mark Foley's inappropriate conduct.    A24    Low-Sulfur Diesel Fuel for Sale  Almost all trucks and buses will soon be able to fill their tanks with diesel fuel containing just 3 percent of the sulfur content in the older fuel.    A22    NEW YORK/REGION   B1-7    New York City Acts to Add Lower-Cost Housing  The Bloomberg administration plans to recommend that the city's most popular tax break for housing developers be overhauled as a way of creating a more powerful incentive to build lower-cost housing.   A1    Guilty Plea in Subway Killing  Andrew Goldstein, a schizophrenic, pleaded guilty to manslaughter, admitting for the first time that he knew what he was doing when he pushed a young writer to her death in front of a subway train seven years ago.    B1    Albany Muslims Convicted  A federal jury in Albany convicted two Muslim immigrants on money- laundering charges, saying they participated in a plot with a man they believed was helping plan a missile attack on a Pakistani diplomat in New York City in 2004.    B1    BUSINESS DAY   C1-14    Inquiry Into Private Equity  The Justice Department is looking into possible anticompetitive behavior in the clubby private equity industry, according to people briefed on the investigation.    C1    Blame May Shift In Spy Case  At least one lawyer involved in the Hewlett-Packard spying case and outside legal experts said the five defendants might turn on each other to shift blame away from themselves.    C3    OPEC Considers Oil Decline  OPEC ministers are still debating how to put a brake on falling oil prices, which have dropped 25 percent since July. abstract: QUESTIONS ON PRIVATE EQUITY Several of the nation's largest private firm have received letters from the Justice Department seeking broad information about the possibility of anticompetitive behavior going back to 2003. [Page C1.]    CONFLICT OVER OIL CUTS OPEC ministers are still debating how to put a brake on falling oil prices. OPEC's current president, Edmund Daukoru, left, who is the Nigerian oil minister, said that ''something must be done,'' and has proposed that OPEC cut production by one million barrels a day from a nominal ceiling of 28 million barrels. But instead of presenting a united front, OPEC's 11 members have found it hard to agree on how quickly to act and how the cuts should be shared. [C1.]    YAHOO LOSES GROUND As Google whips out its fat checkbook again -- this time to buy the YouTube video site -- it is making Yahoo look even more out of step with the rapidly changing Internet advertising market. [C1.]    TAX BREAKS FOR CLERGY A housing deduction is one of several tax breaks that leave extra money in the pockets of clergy members and their religious employers. Ministers of every faith are also exempt from income tax withholding and can opt out of Social Security. And every state but one exempts religious employers from paying state unemployment taxes. [A1.]    MARKETING THE MINI The auto industry is watching the introduction of BMW's new Mini as an important marketing case study. [C1.]    RE-EMERGENCE OF DIESEL A vast majority of trucks and buses will soon be able to fill their tanks with diesel fuel with just 3 percent of the sulfur content in the older fuel. [A22.]    NEW AIRBUS CHIEF WARNS OF CUTS Louis Gallois, the newly appointed chief executive of Airbus, the European plane maker, warned that job cuts would be unavoidable as it wrestled with a reorganization to streamline management and increase productivity. [C3.]    CLAIMS AGAINST COPPER GIANT Asarco, a bankrupt copper giant facing billions of dollars in pollution claims across the nation, pretended for years to recycle metals while illegally burning hazardous wastes in a notorious El Paso smelter, according to newly released Environmental Protection Agency documents. [A18.]    H.P. DEFENDANTS' STRATEGY At least one lawyer involved in the Hewlett-Packard spying case and several outside legal experts say the five defendants might wind up turning on each other as part of a way to shift blame from themselves. [C3.]    TO INDIA FOR HEALTH CARE With medical costs in India routinely 80 percent lower than in the United States, more American employers are exploring sending their workers to India for treatment, raising questions about quality and liability. [C6.]    SPRINT NEXTEL CHAIRMAN TO RETIRE Timothy M. Donahue, executive chairman of the Sprint Nextel Corporation, said that he would retire at the end of the year, in the latest shake-up at a company that has lost ground to its larger rivals Cingular and Verizon Wireless. [C10.]    ROBB REPORT CANCELS AUCTION The publisher of the magazine The Robb Report and other glossy lifestyle guides for the super-wealthy has canceled an auction of the company after failing to attract a sufficiently rich offer. [C10.]    A LAPTOP DEAL WITH LIBYA The government of Libya reached an agreement with One Laptop Per Child, a nonprofit United States group developing an inexpensive, educational laptop computer, with the goal of supplying machines to all 1.2 million Libyan schoolchildren by June of 2008. [A14.]    STOCKS EDGE HIGHER Stocks ended slightly higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average reaching a record close after a seesaw session, as investors proceeded cautiously before the unofficial start of the third-quarter earnings period. [C11.]    IMCLONE CHAIRMAN RESIGNS The embattled chairman of ImClone Systems and another director have resigned, a development that moves the investor Carl Icahn closer to his goal of gaining control of the company's board. ImClone shares rose $1.19, to $31.09, apparently on investor speculation that Mr. Icahn would shake up the company or sell it should he gain control. [C3.]    PSYCHOLOGY OF OVERINDULGENCE Research shows that people are heavily influenced by factors like packaging and portion sizes when they decide how much and what to eat. [F1.]    CLINTON'S EATING CRUSADE Former President Bill Clinton is working on an effort to get junk food out of school vending machines, in part because of his own childhood struggles with his weight. [F5.]    ONLINE    BUSINESS TRAVEL The new reality of business travel includes more unexpected destinations. A special report is at nytimes.com/business.    MUTUAL FUNDS For mutual fund investors, jubilance over gains in the stock market has been tempered by the realization that many fund managers were caught flat-footed and did not keep pace. A special report is at nytimes.com/business.    A FLOWERING MARKET The cut flower industry is a textbook example of how China sets about capturing one market after another. An audio slide show can be found at nytimes.com/business.

abstract: VIENNA — The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council have agreed to start working on sanctions against Iran next week but have failed to bridge differences on how harsh the penalties should be, diplomats and officials said.

abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, on Oct. 19 to discuss a 1 million barrel-a-day output cut.
snippet: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, on Oct. 19 to discuss a 1 million barrel-a-day output cut.
lead_paragraph: Oct. 14 — The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which produces 40 percent of the world’s oil, will hold an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, on Oct. 19 to discuss a 1 million barrel-a-day output cut, an OPEC delegate said.

abstract: THE FOLEY SCANDAL    The News -- Speaker J. Dennis Hastert got an endorsement from President Bush as other House Republicans and aides testified about the Mark Foley e-mail scandal.    Behind the News -- Mr. Hastert has been under pressure to resign following revelations that the House leadership had been warned about the behavior of Mr. Foley, a Florida Republican who sent suggestive messages to Congressional pages. But Mr. Bush said the speaker was doing a ''fine job.'' Mr. Hastert himself threatened to fire any aide found to have been involved in a cover-up of the scandal.    THE KOREAN TEST    The News -- Senator John McCain sought to place the blame for North Korea's nuclear test on the policies of former President Bill Clinton.    Behind the News -- The senator's attack was part of an escalating feud as both parties sought to gain political advantage from the crisis. Mr. McCain and other Republicans faulted the Clinton administration for negotiating with North Korea. But Madeleine K. Albright, secretary of state under Mr. Clinton, and others struck back at the Republicans, arguing that President Bush ignored North Korea for too long.    OPEC    The News -- Members of OPEC fought over how to implement a call by the group's current leader, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, for cuts in production.    Behind the News -- Faced with oil prices that have fallen by nearly 25 percent in two months, Mr. Daukoru suggested cutting production by a million barrels a day. Many of the 11 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agree that cuts must be made, but cannot agree on how to apportion them. OPEC's most influential member, Saudi Arabia, has yet to weigh in on the issue.    THE ELECTIONS    The News -- Outside groups are set to unleash a new barrage of negative television advertisements in Congressional races.    Behind the News -- So-called 527 groups can spend nearly unlimited amounts of money on political activities as long as they have not actively coordinated with candidates or parties. And these groups had raised nearly $200 million as of June 30. One group, Americans for Honesty on Issues, led by a Republican consultant from Houston, plans to spend $1 million on ads attacking nine Democratic candidates including Ken Lucas of Kentucky, above.    #%@?/*!    The News -- In her first tour in 12 years, Barbra Streisand returned to the concert stage in her native New York City and promptly gave a heckling fan a piece of her mind.    Behind the News -- The fan was unhappy because part of the concert featured Ms. Streisand, well known for her Democratic leanings, interrogating a George W. Bush impersonator. So Ms. Streisand shut the fan up with an expletive. But the heckler wasn't the only one upset with that part of the act: reviews praised Ms. Streisand's singing but panned the political performance.

abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which produces 40 percent of the world's oil, will hold an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, on Oct. 19 to discuss a 1 million barrel-a-day output cut, an OPEC delegate said.     The group will convene in Qatar to discuss a voluntary supply cut aimed at reviving oil prices that have fallen by a quarter in the last three months. Members will debate whether to cut actual production or to lower the cartel's 28 million barrel-a-day output quota.

abstract: IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, the president of OPEC, called the drop in crude oil prices since July “catastrophic.” Although the 11 members of OPEC seem to agree on the need to rid world markets of excess oil, the situation gets a bit stickier from there, with countries like Iran and Venezuela vying with bigger producers like Saudi Arabia and Algeria for market share.

abstract: IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING -- Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, the president of OPEC, called the drop in crude oil prices since July ''catastrophic.'' Although the 11 members of OPEC seem to agree on the need to rid world markets of excess oil, the situation gets a bit stickier from there, with countries like Iran and Venezuela vying with bigger producers like Saudi Arabia and Algeria for market share.    TOWARD A BETTER CANAL -- Panamanians will vote in a referendum over whether to add a third set of locks to the Panama Canal (Sunday). The country took over the canal from the United States in 1999, and although there seems to be broad agreement that the project would help bring the outdated canal up to modern standards -- making room for larger ships, for instance, and cutting wait times for vessels lingering offshore -- many Panamanians are skeptical. There is concern, among other things, that the government's $5.2 billion price tag for the seven-year project is a low estimate. Meanwhile, Nicaragua's president has proposed spending $18 billion to build a wider alternative to the Panama Canal.    INDICATORS DU JOUR -- For economic indicators, the focus this week will be on inflation, with the release of the Producer Price Index for September (Tuesday) and the Consumer Price Index for September (Wednesday). Other reports scheduled for release this week are industrial production and capacity utilization for September (Tuesday); housing starts for September (Wednesday); and leading economic indicators (Thursday).    A MONSTER EARNINGS WEEK -- Earnings season gets into full swing with some big names in the Dow. Highlights will include: Intel, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, McClatchy, Merrill Lynch, Motorola and Yahoo (Tuesday); AMR, Apple, Boston Scientific, eBay, General Dynamics and J. P. Morgan Chase (Wednesday); Bank of America, Citigroup, Coca-Cola, Dow Jones, Google, Honeywell, Eli Lilly, McDonald's, Nokia, Southwest Airlines, the Tribune Company and Wyeth (Thursday); and 3M and Merck (Friday).

lead_paragraph: IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING -- Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, the president of OPEC, called the drop in crude oil prices since July "catastrophic." Although the 11 members of OPEC seem to agree on the need to rid world markets of excess oil, the situation gets a bit stickier from there, with countries like Iran and Venezuela vying with bigger producers like Saudi Arabia and Algeria for market share.

abstract: SIMPSON BOOK -- The publisher of the book from O.J. Simpson, in which he hypothesizes about how he could have committed the 1994 murder of his wife, said that she was told the advance and royalties for the book would go to Mr. Simpson's children, not to him. The publisher, Judith Regan, said she believed the book was ''a confession'' by Mr. Simpson to committing the murders of his former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend, Ronald Goldman. [Page C1]    MILTON FRIEDMAN DIES -- Milton Friedman, the grandmaster of free-market economic theory in the postwar era and a prime force in the movement of nations toward less government and greater reliance on individual responsibility, died in San Francisco, where he lived. Conservative and liberal colleagues alike viewed Mr. Friedman, a Nobel laureate, as one of the 20th century's leading economic scholars. [A1]    INFLATION FALLS AGAIN -- Consumer prices fell 0.5 percent for the second straight month in October, suggesting that inflation was being contained by falling energy prices and a slowing economy. Excluding energy and food, so-called core inflation inched ahead 0.1 percent, the slowest pace since February. [C1]    FURTHER DROP IN OIL -- Oil prices fell to their lowest level in a year as oil traders expressed doubt that OPEC members would carry out their recent deal to trim production. Crude oil for December delivery fell $2.50 a barrel, to settle at $56.26, the steepest in 15 months. [C4]    STOCKS GAIN -- Wall Street scored a fifth straight gain and the Dow Jones industrials achieved their third straight record close. The Dow rose 54.11 points, or 0.44 percent, to 12,305.82. [C9]    DEPARTMENT STORES ON THE RISE -- From the modest cubicles inside Macy's headquarters in Cincinnati to the spacious corner offices at Saks Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, merchants are beginning to discuss something virtually unheard of in the American department store industry: a comeback. After four decades of decline, executives say the department store has again become a destination for shoppers. [A1]    BUSH IN VIETNAM -- President Bush begins a 72-hour visit to Vietnam, linked to an annual Asian summit for which the Communist government in Vietnam is the host. Following Republican losses in Congressional elections and the deteriorating situation in Iraq, White House officials concede the visit is poorly timed. [A12]    ENERGY IN MYANMAR -- In the balmy waters of the Bay of Bengal, just off the coast of Myanmar, an Asian energy rush is on. Huge pockets of natural gas have been found. China and India are jostling to sign deals. Plans are afoot to spend billions on new ports and pipelines. Yet onshore not a light is to be seen. People receive two hours of electricity a day from a military government that is among the world's most repressive. [A1]    MEDIA FIRMS IN PRIVATE HANDS -- Some of the largest broadcasters and publishers are being swept into the arms of private equity firms. The trend could raise new regulatory concerns, however, as some of the big private equity firms start to weave a complex web of cross-ownerships in the industry. The latest example is Clear Channel Communications, which has agreed to be acquired for $18.7 billion by Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital. [C1]    CITIGROUP'S CHINA BANK DEAL -- A group of investors led by Citigroup reached a deal to pay about $3.1 billion for a controlling stake in the Guangdong Development Bank, the first time a foreign-led consortium has won the right to manage a major Chinese bank. The deal came after more than a year of intense negotiation with the Chinese government and a contentious bidding war. [C9]    HEWLETT-PACKARD PROFIT -- In a quarter in which it struggled with revelations about corporate spying, Hewlett-Packard still managed to post sharp gains in profit and revenue. Net income for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Oct. 31 rose 27 percent to $1.7 billion, or 60 cents a share, from adjusted amounts a year earlier. Revenue increased 7 percent. [C4]    ICAHN BID FOR RECKSON -- Days before shareholders of Reckson Associates Realty were scheduled to vote on the company's sale to another publicly traded Midtown office landlord, the investor Carl C. Icahn and the privately held Macklowe Properties have submitted a $4.6 billion offer that tops the earlier bid. [C7]    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    Jason Calacanis, the outspoken blogger and entrepreneur who ran AOL's Netscape division, resigned yesterday in the wake of the firing of AOL's chief executive, Jonathan Miller. (NYT)    The Starbucks Corporation said that its fourth-quarter profit slipped 5 percent, blaming the dip on new accounting changes. For the 13 weeks that ended Oct. 1, Starbucks, the world's largest specialty coffee retailer, posted net earnings of $117.3 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $123.7 million, or 16 cents a share, for a year ago. (AP)    Taco Bell will eliminate or reduce trans fats from cooking oils in its American restaurants, the company announced yesterday, making it the latest fast-food chain to do so. Taco Bell, the nation's largest seller of quick-service Mexican-style foods, uses the oils to fry its nachos, taco salad shells, potatoes, chalupa shells and other items. (AP)    Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, said it would begin selling certain generic prescription drugs for $4 in 11 new states, bringing the total to 38 states. Wal-Mart, which started the $4 generic drug program in Florida in September, said it was now available in Idaho, Kentucky, Maine, Massachusetts, Nebraska, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Utah, Washington and West Virginia. (REUTERS)
