abstract: Economic data, corporate earnings and meetings.
snippet: Economic data, corporate earnings and meetings.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include industrial production for February (Monday); import prices for February and housing starts for February (Tuesday); producer price index for February (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, consumer price index for February, fourth-quarter current account deficit, Conference Board leading economic indicators for February, and Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index (Thursday).

abstract: Members are anticipating that a pickup in demand later in the year will mop up extra barrels of oil already being pumped.
snippet: Members are anticipating that a pickup in demand later in the year will mop up extra barrels of oil already being pumped.
lead_paragraph: With oil prices rising tentatively above $80 a barrel as demand picks up in Asia, members of the world’s oil cartel see few reasons to complain. Saudi Arabia’s oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, OPEC’s de facto leader, said this week that oil prices were in a “happy situation.”

abstract: While exports to the United States might rebound this year, in the long run the decline in western demand and the growing importance of China represent a fundamental shift for the oil market.
snippet: While exports to the United States might rebound this year, in the long run the decline in western demand and the growing importance of China represent a fundamental shift for the oil market.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, Saudi Arabia put the final bolt in its largest oil expansion project ever, opening a new field capable of pumping 1.2 million barrels a day — more than the entire production of Texas. The field, called Khurais, was part of an ambitious $60 billion program to increase the kingdom’s production to meet growing energy needs.

abstract: Prices are high enough to drive investment and prompt conservation but low enough for the economy to grow.
snippet: Prices are high enough to drive investment and prompt conservation but low enough for the economy to grow.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices have done something remarkable over the last half-year or so: they have barely budged.

abstract: A chronicler of the first Earth Day describes the limits of environmentalism and new paths to environmental progress.
snippet: A chronicler of the first Earth Day describes the limits of environmentalism and new paths to environmental progress.
lead_paragraph: The genesis of the modern environmental movement was the subject of “Earth Days,” the most recent film by Robert Stone, an Oscar-nominated documentarian who has explored subjects ranging from the space race to the legacy of Lee Harvey Oswald’s life and death. So I thought it worth having a Skype chat with Stone about the meaning of that era, and the crossroads confronting the environmental community now — which relates to the subject of his next film.

abstract: Tuesday | Today’s idea: Our dwindling supply of phosphorus for fertilizer threatens to disrupt food security across the planet during the coming century, an article argues. “This is the gravest natural resource shortage you’ve never heard of.” [Foreign Policy]

abstract: While our lawmakers in Washington are stalling on a bipartisan climate/energy/jobs bill, Beijing is celebrating.
snippet: While our lawmakers in Washington are stalling on a bipartisan climate/energy/jobs bill, Beijing is celebrating.
lead_paragraph: China is having a good week in America. Yes it is. I’d even suggest that there is some high-fiving going on in Beijing. I mean, wouldn’t you if you saw America’s Democratic and Republican leaders conspiring to ensure that America cedes the next great global industry  E.T., energy technology  to China?

lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett says he loves simple things like ice cream. But some 40,000 shareholders at Berkshire Hathaway’s annual meeting in Nebraska this weekend may hear a lot about complex derivatives.

lead_paragraph: President Obama’s handling of the gulf oil spill has been disappointing.

abstract: Russian elites are divided over whether to fight the West or do business with it.

lead_paragraph: “We are not a member of the E.U., but we are a European country.” So spoke President Dmitri Medvedev of Russia in an interview with Western journalists last week, on the eve of the G-20 summit and a key meeting with President Barack Obama in Toronto. His words are worth thinking about.

abstract: “Liberated carbon, it’ll spin your wheels…” A musical blog post on the fossil age.
snippet: “Liberated carbon, it’ll spin your wheels…” A musical blog post on the fossil age.
lead_paragraph: Regular visitors here will be aware that I’m a musician and songwriter in spare microseconds. I was lucky enough to share a stage (a grassy knob really) with Pete Seeger a couple of weeks ago at the Beacon Sloop Club strawberry festival along the Hudson River (along with Steve Stanne, in the middle; photograph by David Rothenberg):

abstract: “South of the Border” is meant to be a documentary but is plagued by the same issues of accuracy that critics have raised about Oliver Stone’s movies.
snippet: “South of the Border” is meant to be a documentary but is plagued by the same issues of accuracy that critics have raised about Oliver Stone’s movies.
lead_paragraph: In feature films about John F. Kennedy, Richard M. Nixon and George W. Bush, Oliver Stone gave free rein to his imagination and was often criticized for doing so. Now, in “South of the Border,” which opened on Friday, he has turned to Hugo Chávez, Venezuela’s controversial populist president, and his reformist allies in South America.

abstract: Two dozen countries representing 80 percent of the world’s commercial energy consumption have announced initiatives to build more efficient appliances and buildings, smart electric grids and electric vehicles.
snippet: Two dozen countries representing 80 percent of the world’s commercial energy consumption have announced initiatives to build more efficient appliances and buildings, smart electric grids and electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Two dozen countries representing 80 percent of the world’s commercial energy consumption on Tuesday announced initiatives to build more efficient appliances and buildings, “smart” electric grids and electric vehicles.

abstract: The stakes are high for getting an energy bill passed this year. What will it take for a compromise?
snippet: The stakes are high for getting an energy bill passed this year. What will it take for a compromise?
lead_paragraph: The hour is late, but there is still a sliver of time to pass a serious energy bill out of this Congress. To do so, though, would require President Obama to rustle up votes with a passion that he has failed to exhibit up to now, and, more importantly, it would require at least seven Republican senators to put the national interest above party and politics. Yes, I know that is all unlikely. You can laugh now. But just remember this: If we don’t get a serious energy bill out of this Congress, and Republicans retake the House and Senate, we may not have another shot until the next presidential term or until we get a “perfect storm”  a climate or energy crisis that is awful enough to finally end our debate on these issues but not so awful as to end the world. But, hey, by 2012, China should pretty much own the clean-tech industry and we’ll at least be able to get some good deals on electric cars.

abstract: Mr. Akins, the State Department’s ambassador to Saudi Arabia, warned more than a year in advance of the 1973 Arab oil embargo that oil-exporting nations were poised to restrict shipments.
snippet: Mr. Akins, the State Department’s ambassador to Saudi Arabia, warned more than a year in advance of the 1973 Arab oil embargo that oil-exporting nations were poised to restrict shipments.
lead_paragraph: James E. Akins, the State Department’s top energy expert and then ambassador to Saudi Arabia, who warned more than a year in advance of the 1973 Arab oil embargo that oil-exporting nations were poised to restrict shipments, died on July 15 in Mitchellville, Md. He was 83.

abstract: Emirati officials said a boat loaded with homemade explosives damaged an oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz last week.
snippet: Emirati officials said a boat loaded with homemade explosives damaged an oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz last week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Investigators in the United Arab Emirates said Friday that a terrorist attack caused the mysterious damage a Japanese oil tanker suffered last week as it passed through the Strait of Hormuz, raising fears of future attacks in the narrow channel that serves as a passageway for shipping crude oil from the Middle East to the rest of the world.

abstract: Is Wall Street in for a long funk?
snippet: Is Wall Street in for a long funk?
lead_paragraph: It has been three decades since Business Week proclaimed “The Death of Equities” on its cover. That 1979 obituary for the stock market, published when the Dow Jones industrial average languished at a mere 875, became a symbol of an age of doubt. So shattered were ordinary Americans by gas lines, recessions and double-digit inflation that they resorted to pulling cash out of equity mutual funds — for eight straight years.

abstract: Canpotex, which is owned by three Canadian potash producers, negotiates long-term, often secret, pricing agreements with offshore customers.
snippet: Canpotex, which is owned by three Canadian potash producers, negotiates long-term, often secret, pricing agreements with offshore customers.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA  It is hardly a household word like, say, the oil cartel OPEC. That is why Canpotex, an organization with a corner on Canada’s potash production, used to go about its business in nearly complete obscurity.

abstract: Canpotex, which is owned by three Canadian potash producers, negotiates long-term, often secret, pricing agreements with offshore customers.

abstract: Reflections on anniversaries for America’s clean-air law and the planet’s oil cartel.
snippet: Reflections on anniversaries for America’s clean-air law and the planet’s oil cartel.
lead_paragraph: Today is the 40th birthday of the Clean Air Act and the 50th birthday of OPEC, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. A 50th anniversary Web page has lots of pictures (none of the long lines of cars waiting for gas in the United States in 1973) and statements about the enduring influence of this small cluster of countries.

abstract: How Olivier Assayas has extended the territory of French cinema.
snippet: How Olivier Assayas has extended the territory of French cinema.
lead_paragraph: 'You are now in French territory.'

abstract: Venezuela has granted BP permission to negotiate the sale of its assets in the South American OPEC member, Venezuelan Oil Minister Rafael Ramirez said on Sunday, Reuters reported.
snippet: Venezuela has granted BP permission to negotiate the sale of its assets in the South American OPEC member, Venezuelan Oil Minister Rafael Ramirez said on Sunday, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela has granted BP permission to negotiate the sale of its assets in the South American O.P.E.C. member, the Venezuelan oil minister, Rafael Ramirez, said Sunday, Reuters reported.

abstract: The New York Film Festival has strengthened its lineup of quality movies after last year’s solemn and misanthropic fare.
snippet: The New York Film Festival has strengthened its lineup of quality movies after last year’s solemn and misanthropic fare.
lead_paragraph: The quickest way to measure the breadth of this year’s revitalized New York Film Festival is to compare its two “social” movies. David Fincher’s sensational, hyperkinetic “Social Network,” which opened the festival, feels like a once-in-a-generation movie that could affect Hollywood, much as the Facebook phenomenon whose creation it chronicles has rocked modern communications. “Film Socialisme” is the latest cryptic essay on language, semiotics and film technology by Jean-Luc Godard, the French New Wave prophet who turns 80 in December. Avaricious young hotshots and a grumpy old master: that the festival accords them equal respect is a sign of its renewed vigor.

abstract: Sinopec’s $7.1 billion investment in Repsol’s Brazilian subsidiary is the latest in a string of energy deals in which the Chinese are recycling their enormous stockpile of dollars.
snippet: Sinopec’s $7.1 billion investment in Repsol’s Brazilian subsidiary is the latest in a string of energy deals in which the Chinese are recycling their enormous stockpile of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Sinopec’s $7.1 billion investment in Repsol’s Brazilian subsidiary is the latest in a string of energy deals involving state-controlled Chinese companies.

abstract: “Carlos,” directed by Olivier Assayas, grew from a planned 90-minute film to a five-and-a-half-hour exploration of an international terrorist.
snippet: “Carlos,” directed by Olivier Assayas, grew from a planned 90-minute film to a five-and-a-half-hour exploration of an international terrorist.
lead_paragraph: EVERYTHING about “Carlos,” the new film from the French director Olivier Assayas, is large and ambitious, from its length — about five and a half hours — to its subject matter: the rise and fall of the international terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal. But that’s not how things started.

abstract: The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan said that it planned a number of measures that would benefit the Canadian province.
snippet: The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan said that it planned a number of measures that would benefit the Canadian province.
lead_paragraph: The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan suddenly wants to live up to its name. The company, seeking to fend off a $39 billion bid from BHP Billiton by winning over local politicians and their constituents, said Wednesday that it planned a number of measures that would benefit the Canadian province.

abstract: Saskatchewan, the home province of the Potash Corporation, officially opposed the $39 billion takeover offer by the mining giant BHP Billiton, saying it “does not provide a “net benefit” to the people of Saskatchewan and Canada.”
snippet: Saskatchewan, the home province of the Potash Corporation, officially opposed the $39 billion takeover offer by the mining giant BHP Billiton, saying it “does not provide a “net benefit” to the people of Saskatchewan and Canada.”
lead_paragraph: Saskatchewan, the province where the Potash Corporation is based, on Thursday officially opposed the $39 billion takeover offer by the mining giant BHP Billiton, saying it “does not provide a ‘net benefit’ to the people of Saskatchewan and Canada.”

abstract: In “Carlos,” Olivier Assayas’s fictionalization of the life and brutal times of Carlos the Jackal, idealism is cross-cut with violence, and heroes with villains.
snippet: In “Carlos,” Olivier Assayas’s fictionalization of the life and brutal times of Carlos the Jackal, idealism is cross-cut with violence, and heroes with villains.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a soldier, I’m not a martyr,” Carlos the Jackal announces in “Carlos,” Olivier Assayas’s fictionalization of the life and brutal times of the Marxist turned mercenary. Carlos delivers this line in 1975 during a re-creation of a heated exchange with the radical true believers with whom he has taken OPEC ministers hostage. It was one of the more spectacular operations in his career as a self-professed professional revolutionary, and he had carefully dressed for the part in a black beret and leather jacket meant to invoke Che Guevara, pop martyr supreme.

abstract: David Stockman, Reagan’s budget guru, thinks Congress should let the Bush tax cuts lapse.
snippet: David Stockman, Reagan’s budget guru, thinks Congress should let the Bush tax cuts lapse.
lead_paragraph: David Stockman has never been one to shy away from a roaring economic-policy debate. The former boy-wonder budget director in the first Reagan administration and the architect of Reagan’s supply-side economic policies, Stockman has been very busy lately rejecting the tax-cutting recommendations of Republicans in Washington and arguing that we must get our fiscal house in order or watch our way of life continue its decline. As an “imperialist power,” he says, America is in danger of being at “sundown.” Stockman, who turned 64 on Wednesday, has always been ahead of the curve on tax and fiscal issues, and it appears that he is ahead of it again this time, too.

abstract: Recent discoveries of oil and natural gas fields and new mining technology have combined to help increase the world’s supply of energy for decades to come.
snippet: Recent discoveries of oil and natural gas fields and new mining technology have combined to help increase the world’s supply of energy for decades to come.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON

abstract: A bipartisan group says that subsidies and tariffs to spur domestic production are “fiscally irresponsible and environmentally unwise.”
snippet: A bipartisan group says that subsidies and tariffs to spur domestic production are “fiscally irresponsible and environmentally unwise.”
lead_paragraph: Subsidies and tariffs to promote domestic ethanol production are “fiscally irresponsible and environmentally unwise” and should be ended, a bipartisan group of United States senators declared in a letter to the chamber’s leaders on Tuesday.

abstract: A serious effort is afoot to change the name of the Texas Railroad Commission and replace its three members with part-time gubernatorial appointees, as there are at most of the state’s other regulatory agencies.
snippet: A serious effort is afoot to change the name of the Texas Railroad Commission and replace its three members with part-time gubernatorial appointees, as there are at most of the state’s other regulatory agencies.
lead_paragraph: Texas has three railroad commissioners, who are elected statewide. They regulate oil and gas, which you’d never know from their title. But that’s not the only reason there’s a serious effort afoot to change the agency’s name and replace those officeholders with part-time gubernatorial appointees, as there are at most of the state’s other regulatory agencies.

abstract: Avarice and the implications of technology were prominent movie themes in 2010, in “Inception” and “The Social Network,” for example.
snippet: Avarice and the implications of technology were prominent movie themes in 2010, in “Inception” and “The Social Network,” for example.
lead_paragraph: Capitalism and con artistry: the economic catastrophe we faced in 2008 may have been avoided, at least for now. But it left behind a reservoir of dread and cynicism that have seeped into every corner of American life, even the movies. That unease found its way into one 2010 megahit, Christopher Nolan’s diabolical “Inception.” However convoluted and impenetrable, this cinematic labyrinth sabotages the very idea of reality with its notion of dream invasion, theft and implantation.

abstract: Washington has worried that terrorists will become hackers. Perhaps we all should worry that hackers will become terrorists.
snippet: Washington has worried that terrorists will become hackers. Perhaps we all should worry that hackers will become terrorists.
lead_paragraph: 2010 was the year that removed all doubt that cybersecurity is now a geopolitical problem.

abstract: Mr. Pérez tried to make Venezuela a leader of the developing world during a 1970s oil boom only to have his legacy upended.
snippet: Mr. Pérez tried to make Venezuela a leader of the developing world during a 1970s oil boom only to have his legacy upended.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Carlos Andrés Pérez, the former president who tried to make Venezuela a leader of the developing world during a 1970s oil boom only to have his legacy upended in a tumultuous 1989 return to the presidency marked by civil unrest, coup attempts, impeachment and exile, died Saturday in Miami. He was 88.

abstract: Recent years have been humbling for oil bulls, but they should hang on to that humility. More oil and natural gas are coming on stream.
snippet: Recent years have been humbling for oil bulls, but they should hang on to that humility. More oil and natural gas are coming on stream.
lead_paragraph: Oil bulls are once again kicking up dust. The intensifying struggle to lift output, they say, will collide with the insatiable thirst of an expanding Asia to push oil above $100 a barrel. In fact, the cost of crude may be held down as demand growth is cut by half as producers from Russia to Africa via Brazil ramp up supply.

abstract: For the automotive industry, 2010 played out like a reality show, with heroes and villains, surprising alliances, narrow escapes and thrilling reversals of fortune.
snippet: For the automotive industry, 2010 played out like a reality show, with heroes and villains, surprising alliances, narrow escapes and thrilling reversals of fortune.
lead_paragraph: THE last year in automobiles could have been mistaken for an episode of “Survivor,” only set in the urban jungle of Detroit rather than some tropical backwater.

abstract: The Energy Department has more than doubled its estimates of recoverable shale natural gas reserves. The price is good. What is Congress waiting for?
snippet: The Energy Department has more than doubled its estimates of recoverable shale natural gas reserves. The price is good. What is Congress waiting for?

abstract: Paris hopes to use its presidency of the Group of 20 nations to place better regulation of food and energy markets on the agenda.
snippet: Paris hopes to use its presidency of the Group of 20 nations to place better regulation of food and energy markets on the agenda.
lead_paragraph: PARIS  Rising prices for basic commodities could derail the fragile economic recovery by pushing up inflation in developed countries and stoking social tensions in developing ones. But could the recent escalation in energy and food prices actually be a boon to the world economy by leading to greater security of supply, better regulation and more transparent pricing?

abstract: As oil prices inch toward a two-year high of $100 a barrel, there will be more benefits to oil-dependent Gulf states' economies than meets the eye.
snippet: As oil prices inch toward a two-year high of $100 a barrel, there will be more benefits to oil-dependent Gulf states' economies than meets the eye.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI — That rising oil prices will help Gulf countries recover from the global economic crisis quicker than non-oil-producing nations may appear to be stating the obvious. But economists point out that as prices inch toward a two-year high of $100 a barrel, there will be more benefits to these oil-dependent economies than meets the eye.

abstract: A buildup in stocks related to rising oil imports derived from Canadian oil sands has helped make crude significantly cheaper in the United States than it is in Europe or Asia.
snippet: A buildup in stocks related to rising oil imports derived from Canadian oil sands has helped make crude significantly cheaper in the United States than it is in Europe or Asia.
lead_paragraph: In case you haven’t noticed, oil prices in the United States differ from those in the rest of the world. Usually the variance is just a few dollars, but over the last few weeks the difference between West Texas Intermediate prices and Brent crude, which is sourced in Europe’s North Sea, has widened to about $10.

abstract: Egypt is not a major oil exporter, but it is a crucial link for petroleum products headed from the Middle East to Europe and the United States.
snippet: Egypt is not a major oil exporter, but it is a crucial link for petroleum products headed from the Middle East to Europe and the United States.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As violence has broken out in Egypt, concern has turned to the risk of the blocking of the Suez Canal or nearby pipelines, which could pose a threat to world energy supplies.

abstract: Questions persist over whether Saudi Arabia’s long-term reserves are overstated.
snippet: Questions persist over whether Saudi Arabia’s long-term reserves are overstated.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s ability to boost oil production much above current levels is questionable and the country’s overall crude reserves may have been overstated by up to 40 percent, American diplomats in Riyadh warned in confidential cables written between 2007 and 2009. The dispatches were released by Wikileaks and published on Tuesday by The Guardian newspaper in Britain.

abstract: The oil markets are nervous with the possibility of disruptions in the Middle East and North Africa, which account for some 35 percent of production.
snippet: The oil markets are nervous with the possibility of disruptions in the Middle East and North Africa, which account for some 35 percent of production.
lead_paragraph: PARIS  The turmoil in North Africa and the Middle East has helped drive oil prices up to more than $102 a barrel for an important benchmark crude, Brent, although so far there have been no significant disruptions in production or supply, according to experts at the International Energy Agency here.

abstract: While oil groups said the financial effect of the disruptions should be limited, investors feared that unrest could hamper production and exploration.
snippet: While oil groups said the financial effect of the disruptions should be limited, investors feared that unrest could hamper production and exploration.
lead_paragraph: LONDON  Global oil companies said Monday that they were making plans to evacuate employees in Libya after some operations there were disrupted by political unrest. Libya holds the largest crude oil reserves in Africa, and the moves drove some stock prices down and a crucial oil benchmark to a three-year high.

abstract: The country's target of a fivefold increase in oil production this decade may be unrealistic give the hurdles that have to be cleared, but half that amount may be achievable.
snippet: The country's target of a fivefold increase in oil production this decade may be unrealistic give the hurdles that have to be cleared, but half that amount may be achievable.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Iraq’s goal of a fivefold surge in oil production capacity this decade to rival Saudi Arabia’s dominance in world markets will almost surely have to be revised, industry experts say, because of technical and skilled labor limitations and the country’s self-interest in defending high international crude prices.

abstract: Turmoil in the Arab world drove oil prices higher and stocks lower despite efforts by Saudi Arabia to calm turbulent markets.
snippet: Turmoil in the Arab world drove oil prices higher and stocks lower despite efforts by Saudi Arabia to calm turbulent markets.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  The political turmoil sweeping the Arab world drove oil prices sharply higher and stocks much lower on Tuesday despite efforts by Saudi Arabia to calm turbulent markets.

abstract: Readers respond to articles about the uprisings in Libya and the Arab world.
snippet: Readers respond to articles about the uprisings in Libya and the Arab world.

snippet: A spike in the price of oil has many wondering how high it will go and what the fallout could be to recovery in the United States.
lead_paragraph: This is no oil shock  not yet, anyway.

abstract: Any interruptions from countries like Iran, Oman and Iraq would further tighten oil supplies.
snippet: Any interruptions from countries like Iran, Oman and Iraq would further tighten oil supplies.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Just when oil markets appeared to be calming, crude oil prices surged again on Tuesday as the potential for more oil shipment disruptions spread across the Middle East and North Africa.

snippet: Washington lobbyists for Arab nations are trying to stay ahead of events without being seen as aiding despots.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For years, they have been one of the most formidable lobbying forces in town: the elite band of former members of Congress, former diplomats and power brokers who have helped Middle Eastern nations navigate diplomatic waters here on delicate issues like arms deals, terrorism, oil and trade restrictions.

abstract: A top aide to the Venezuelan leader, Hugo Chávez, said Colonel Qaddafi accepted a proposal to negotiate a solution to the turmoil in Libya, but one of the colonel’s sons appeared to reject the idea.
snippet: A top aide to the Venezuelan leader, Hugo Chávez, said Colonel Qaddafi accepted a proposal to negotiate a solution to the turmoil in Libya, but one of the colonel’s sons appeared to reject the idea.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government has accepted a proposal by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela to negotiate a solution to the turmoil in Libya, a top aide to Mr. Chávez said on Thursday. But confusion emerged after Colonel Qaddafi’s son reportedly rejected the plan.

abstract: The administration says that excess production capacity is well above what has been disrupted by unrest in the Middle East.
snippet: The administration says that excess production capacity is well above what has been disrupted by unrest in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As oil prices have risen in recent weeks, calls have been growing in Congress for the Obama administration to consider tapping into the nation’s strategic petroleum reserve, which is now at its full capacity of 727 million barrels.

snippet: Perceptions of stability in Russia and instability in OPEC have lifted the ruble and Russian Micex index.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Whatever the eventual outcome of the Arab world’s social upheaval, there is a clear economic winner so far: Vladimir V. Putin.

abstract: Tokyo residents are learning that things they have taken for granted can quickly slip beyond their reach.
snippet: Tokyo residents are learning that things they have taken for granted can quickly slip beyond their reach.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan, a country lulled by the reassuring rhythms of order and predictability, has been jolted by earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis into an unsettling new reality: lack of control.

snippet: Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, delivered a long floor speech rebutting claims that Obama administration policies rather than Middle East uncertainties have driven up prices.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, President Obama’s foes in Congress and industry have sought to pin the blame for rising gasoline prices — now averaging above $3.50 a gallon — on his administration’s energy policies.

abstract: Coziness between businesses and their regulatory agencies over the last few years has led to a series of debacles, from Wall Street to the Gulf of Mexico.
snippet: Coziness between businesses and their regulatory agencies over the last few years has led to a series of debacles, from Wall Street to the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Sheila C. Bair may unwittingly have discovered a simple litmus test for bank regulator effectiveness. As chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, she faced catcalls last week from a mob of community bankers. She was taken aback by the booing. But in fact, watchdogs should bask in such disdain if it means they are doing their jobs.

abstract: As the price of fuels rises, energy specialists say the United States should make some of the hard choices now to end dependence on foreign supplies of oil.
snippet: As the price of fuels rises, energy specialists say the United States should make some of the hard choices now to end dependence on foreign supplies of oil.
lead_paragraph: IMAGINE a foreign policy version of the movie “Groundhog Day,” with Bill Murray playing the president of the United States. The alarm clock rings. Political mayhem is again shaking the Middle East, crude oil and gasoline prices are climbing, and an economic recovery is under threat.

abstract: Oman has a lot of work to do to create jobs for its young people, but when protests began to sweep the Arab world last month, they quickly fizzled out there. Why?
snippet: Oman has a lot of work to do to create jobs for its young people, but when protests began to sweep the Arab world last month, they quickly fizzled out there. Why?
lead_paragraph: MUSCAT — More than half of Oman’s 2.8 million people are under the age of 20, and 83 percent are under 35. It is not surprising then that a chief complaint of Omani citizens is a lack of jobs and training for the sultanate’s young population.

abstract: Oil ministers and executives speaking at a conference in Paris said too many factors were propping up crude prices to expect a decline anytime soon.
snippet: Oil ministers and executives speaking at a conference in Paris said too many factors were propping up crude prices to expect a decline anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Depending on your standpoint — industry, producer or consumer — the current elevated oil price might be caused by speculation, political instability or stronger demand for fossil fuels from improving growth.

abstract: One report attributed the rise in oil prices to the growing perception that the conflict in Libya might not end anytime soon.
snippet: One report attributed the rise in oil prices to the growing perception that the conflict in Libya might not end anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: Stocks slipped as oil prices climbed further on Friday, with traders betting that the conflict in Libya could disrupt oil production there for longer than expected.

abstract: Natural gas is cheaper than oil. It’s cleaner. And it’s ours. Congress should take action.
snippet: Natural gas is cheaper than oil. It’s cleaner. And it’s ours. Congress should take action.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, amid all the hullabaloo over the budget battles, a simple, discrete and largely overlooked bill was dropped into the Congressional hopper. Sponsored by two Democrats and two Republicans — that’s right: an actual bipartisan piece of legislation — its official title is the New Alternative Transportation to Give Americans Solutions Act, or the Nat Gas Act, for short. People in the know, however, call it the Boone Pickens bill.

abstract: After some pushback from passionate readers, still making the case for “frack, baby, frack.”
snippet: After some pushback from passionate readers, still making the case for “frack, baby, frack.”
lead_paragraph: Oh, puh-leeze!

abstract: Some analysts agreed with Saudi Arabia that the world was amply supplied with oil, but others wondered whether the Saudis were able to increase their production at all.
snippet: Some analysts agreed with Saudi Arabia that the world was amply supplied with oil, but others wondered whether the Saudis were able to increase their production at all.
lead_paragraph: With political turmoil spreading across North Africa and the Middle East and oil and gasoline prices rising, all eyes in the energy world are on Saudi Arabia. So when the Saudis announced last weekend that they had cut oil production by 800,000 barrels a day only weeks after they said they would meet any supply gap left by the civil war in Libya, oil analysts offered an array of interpretations.

abstract: Speaking in New Hampshire, Donald Trump takes credit for the release of President Obama’s long-form birth certificate but says it has to be validated by experts.
snippet: Speaking in New Hampshire, Donald Trump takes credit for the release of President Obama’s long-form birth certificate but says it has to be validated by experts.
lead_paragraph: 12:39 p.m. | Updated  PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Donald Trump arrived here Wednesday morning, stepped off a helicopter emblazoned with his name and flashed a wide smile as he took credit for the release of President Obama’s long-form birth certificate.

abstract: President Obama’s decision to weigh into the debate over the authenticity of his citizenship added a layer of complexity to Donald Trump’s arrival in New Hampshire.
snippet: President Obama’s decision to weigh into the debate over the authenticity of his citizenship added a layer of complexity to Donald Trump’s arrival in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Donald J. Trump descended from a black helicopter emblazoned with his name, strode across the tarmac and stood for 30 seconds until he made sure the cameras were in place.

abstract: Autocratic regimes in the Middle East and North Africa relieve social pressures by offering their people all kinds of goodies, including subsidies at the pump. This tends to undercut productivity, raise local oil and gas consumption and leave less oil for export.
snippet: Autocratic regimes in the Middle East and North Africa relieve social pressures by offering their people all kinds of goodies, including subsidies at the pump. This tends to undercut productivity, raise local oil and gas consumption and leave less...
lead_paragraph: There’s no mystery in why all the unrest in North Africa and the Middle East would cause oil and gasoline prices to soar. Libya’s high quality sweet crude is almost off the market entirely, and it’s anyone’s guess when the next oil producer is going to suffer a revolution that could cripple production.

abstract: Nationwide, most drivers have not changed their habits much, which suggests that prices will advance again before long.
snippet: Nationwide, most drivers have not changed their habits much, which suggests that prices will advance again before long.
lead_paragraph: There’s a saying in the oil business: The best cure for high oil prices is high oil prices. In other words, when prices are high, consumers are supposed to buy less at the pump and oil companies are supposed to produce more because it is more profitable to do so.

abstract: Oil prices plummeted by almost 9 percent on Thursday as traders worried that American drivers were beginning to balk at the price of gasoline.
snippet: Oil prices plummeted by almost 9 percent on Thursday as traders worried that American drivers were beginning to balk at the price of gasoline.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices closed below $100 a barrel on Thursday during a session in which most commodity prices fell sharply, signaling that a recent run-up in commodities prices may finally be coming to an end.

abstract: Many energy experts and economists say that oil prices are bound to rebound again because the fundamentals of the global market have not changed very much.
snippet: Many energy experts and economists say that oil prices are bound to rebound again because the fundamentals of the global market have not changed very much.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices have plunged this week like they haven’t since the fall of 2008, when Lehman Brothers failed and a hurricane closed so many refineries that demand for crude dried up for more than a week.

abstract: The price of oil is still almost 30 percent higher than a year ago. “This is a correction, and not a shift in trend,” one analyst said of the recent fall in prices.
snippet: The price of oil is still almost 30 percent higher than a year ago. “This is a correction, and not a shift in trend,” one analyst said of the recent fall in prices.

abstract: The country needs a serious energy policy, not more pandering to the oil industry.
snippet: The country needs a serious energy policy, not more pandering to the oil industry.
lead_paragraph: With the country again facing $4-a-gallon gasoline, the time would seem ripe for a grown-up conversation on energy. What we are getting instead is a mindless rerun of the drill-baby-drill operatics of the 2008 campaign, when gas was also at $4 a gallon. Then, as now, opportunistic politicians insisted that vastly expanded oil drilling would bring relief at the pump and reduced dependence on foreign oil. Then, as now, these arguments were bogus.

abstract: The International Energy Agency cut its forecast for crude oil demand next year, citing the recent surge in petroleum prices and weakening growth prospects for industrialized countries.
snippet: The International Energy Agency cut its forecast for crude oil demand next year, citing the recent surge in petroleum prices and weakening growth prospects for industrialized countries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The International Energy Agency on Thursday cut its forecast for crude oil demand next year as a result of the recent surge in petroleum prices and weakening growth prospects for industrialized countries.

abstract: The International Energy Agency expressed “serious concern” that the increase in oil prices was having negative effects on the global economy.
snippet: The International Energy Agency expressed “serious concern” that the increase in oil prices was having negative effects on the global economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Expressing “serious concern” about elevated crude oil prices, the International Energy Agency on Thursday called for an increase in world oil production. It was an unusual move that highlighted consumer countries’ frustration at the failure of oil-producing nations to lift output in the face of rising demand and tighter supply.

abstract: Having appointed himself temporary oil minister, Iran’s leader is likely to add drama to what is usually a staid proceeding.
snippet: Having appointed himself temporary oil minister, Iran’s leader is likely to add drama to what is usually a staid proceeding.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, is expected to lead next month’s OPEC conference in Vienna as he presses for higher oil prices to aid Iran’s struggling economy, while also seeking to protect and consolidate his power at home as he confronts a growing split with the nation’s supreme leader.

abstract: The Guardian Council has ruled that President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad overstepped his authority by assuming control of the Oil Ministry when he fired the oil minister a week ago.
snippet: The Guardian Council has ruled that President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad overstepped his authority by assuming control of the Oil Ministry when he fired the oil minister a week ago.
lead_paragraph: The Guardian Council, Iran’s top legal panel, has ruled that President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad overstepped his authority by assuming control of the Oil Ministry when he fired the oil minister a week ago, the state-run Fars news agency reported Friday. The report casts doubt on whether Mr. Ahmadinejad will be able to lead the OPEC meeting in Vienna next month, and suggests a further deterioration of his relationship with Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the country’s supreme leader. The Guardian Council is partly appointed by the ayatollah. The council has not confirmed the report, which said that the president’s appointment of himself as acting oil minister was unconstitutional. Last month, Mr. Ahmadinejad tried to dismiss the intelligence chief, but was reversed by Ayatollah Khamenei.

abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s decision appeared to show a retreat in his struggle with Iran’s supreme leader.
snippet: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s decision appeared to show a retreat in his struggle with Iran’s supreme leader.
lead_paragraph: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran will not preside over — or even attend — next month’s OPEC meeting in Vienna as previously planned, Iran’s Foreign Ministry said Tuesday. The change in plan, reported late Monday in Iran’s state-run press, appeared to signify a retreat by the president in his power struggle with the nation’s supreme leader.

abstract: The City Family, which has a pleasant name but strongly resembles a powerful political machine, is making a noticeable comeback.
snippet: The City Family, which has a pleasant name but strongly resembles a powerful political machine, is making a noticeable comeback.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

lead_paragraph: As OPEC ministers prepare to meet Wednesday for the first time since political turmoil spread across North Africa and the Middle East, there are signs that Saudi Arabia and other oil producers are beginning to raise production modestly to help meet global demand.

That left existing quotas in place, despite rising world prices and pressure from major oil-consuming countries to increase output.

lead_paragraph: The arrival of Labor Day means the unofficial end of summer, barbecues in the park and, for tens of millions of Americans, road trips.

abstract: Building more housing in cities will make them more dense, but everyone will benefit.
snippet: Building more housing in cities will make them more dense, but everyone will benefit.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Avent is an economics correspondent for The Economist and author of the Kindle Single “The Gated City,” from which this essay is adapted.

abstract: New fields in the Americas are an emerging prize in the global energy market, with Western oil companies looking to exploit untapped reserves in a part of the world with greater political stability.
snippet: New fields in the Americas are an emerging prize in the global energy market, with Western oil companies looking to exploit untapped reserves in a part of the world with greater political stability.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil has begun building its first nuclear submarine to protect its vast, new offshore oil discoveries. Colombia’s oil production is climbing so fast that it is closing in on Algeria’s and could hit Libya’s prewar levels in a few years. ExxonMobil is striking new deals in Argentina, which recently heralded its biggest oil discovery since the 1980s.

abstract: In “The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World,” Daniel Yergin returns to the topic of how energy policy is driving global change.
snippet: In “The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World,” Daniel Yergin returns to the topic of how energy policy is driving global change.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Yergin is America’s most influential energy pundit, and the book that put him on the map was “The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power” (1991). It was a best seller, won a Pulitzer Prize and was tailored into a popular PBS mini-series. In the two decades since, Mr. Yergin, operating as a kind of one-man think tank, has had a virtual monopoly on the subject of energy and geopolitics. Such is his influence that one half expects his competitors to file antitrust litigation against him.

abstract: Competition is essential to the American way of life, and it should extend to our fuel market.
snippet: Competition is essential to the American way of life, and it should extend to our fuel market.
lead_paragraph: OUR country has just gone through a sober national retrospective on the 9/11 attacks. Apart from the heartfelt honoring of those lost — on that day and since — what seemed most striking is our seeming passivity and indifference toward the well from which our enemies draw their political strength and financial power: the strategic importance of oil, which provides the wherewithal for a generational war against us, as we mutter diplomatic niceties.

abstract: Saudi Arabia and other Gulf producers raised their output this summer to make up for the stall in Libyan exports.
snippet: Saudi Arabia and other Gulf producers raised their output this summer to make up for the stall in Libyan exports.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI — Gulf members of OPEC will cut their output of oil once Libya’s production is back on track, Abdullah al-Badri, secretary general of OPEC, said this week.

abstract: The move by Eni, the largest foreign player in the Libyan oil industry, marks an important step toward the stabilization of the country’s economy.
snippet: The move by Eni, the largest foreign player in the Libyan oil industry, marks an important step toward the stabilization of the country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Eni, the Italian oil company, said Monday that it had restarted oil production in some of its Libyan oil wells, the first time it has done so since Western companies fled the turmoil that followed the uprising this year against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

abstract: New finds, technological advances and fresh access to some countries could change the global energy map, but the new opportunities come with a dizzying array of risks.
snippet: New finds, technological advances and fresh access to some countries could change the global energy map, but the new opportunities come with a dizzying array of risks.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Opportunities in oil and natural gas have rarely been so bountiful. New finds and technological advances and fresh access to some countries are pushing exploration and production into areas once considered peripheral.

abstract: Reading the current energy map requires great care, and the understanding that it could change unexpectedly. But OPEC has the reserve capacity to iron out the bumps.
snippet: Reading the current energy map requires great care, and the understanding that it could change unexpectedly. But OPEC has the reserve capacity to iron out the bumps.
lead_paragraph: Whether we consider economic or political factors, reading the new energy map of 2011 is difficult. Political instability in the oil exporting countries of the Middle East and North Africa has led to changes in governments, new political actors and, in some cases, a temporary suspension of oil producing and exporting activities.

abstract: Maria van der Hoeven, the new executive director of the International Energy Agency, discusses her priorities, the role of renewable sources and the changing global energy map.
snippet: Maria van der Hoeven, the new executive director of the International Energy Agency, discusses her priorities, the role of renewable sources and the changing global energy map.
lead_paragraph: Maria van der Hoeven, a former economics minister in the Netherlands, took over as executive director of the International Energy Agency in September. She is the second female head of the I.E.A., which was created in 1974 after an embargo by Arab countries sharply raised oil prices and curbed economic growth. Comprising 28 members including Germany, Japan and the United States, the I.E.A. is tasked with gathering reliable information and responding to supply disruptions. Ms. van der Hoeven takes over amid concerns that the I.E.A. is losing relevancy because emerging energy giants like China are not members, and after a rare public split in June within the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries about whether to raise production levels in response to unrest in Libya. Ms. van der Hoeven responded in writing to questions from James Kanter.

abstract: Brazil, which is maintaining investments to increase oil production even as turmoil hits financial markets, is leading a shift in Latin America’s oil industry.
snippet: Brazil, which is maintaining investments to increase oil production even as turmoil hits financial markets, is leading a shift in Latin America’s oil industry.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Of all those who might smile at Brazil’s unfolding oil boom, Walter Link could rank near the top. A U.S. oilman here at a time of nationalist fervor, he was the former chief geologist for Standard Oil Company of New Jersey whom Brazil hired to find its oil reserves.

abstract: An oil industry strike last month has snowballed into public-sector actions by bank, health care and industrial workers.
snippet: An oil industry strike last month has snowballed into public-sector actions by bank, health care and industrial workers.
lead_paragraph: Three thousand striking customs officers disrupted oil shipments from Kuwait on Monday, escalating the labor unrest that has been gaining momentum in recent weeks in the emirate.

abstract: Simply put, there has been no lasting oil shock from the Arab Spring.
snippet: Simply put, there has been no lasting oil shock from the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: When revolts broke out from Tunisia to Bahrain last winter and spring, alarm bells rang out across global oil markets. Prices of various benchmark crude oils soared as traders, policy makers and industry analysts feared a repeat of the kind of oil price upheavals that had shaken the global economy several times in the 1970s.

abstract: Certain countries — including Iran, France and Russia — have periodically floated the idea of transforming the markets by settling crude oil transactions in currencies other than the dollar.
snippet: Certain countries — including Iran, France and Russia — have periodically floated the idea of transforming the markets by settling crude oil transactions in currencies other than the dollar.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The dollar is here to stay, at least as far as pricing in oil markets is concerned.

abstract: China's growing energy needs are making the idea of a trans-Pacific market for Canadian oil increasingly attractive.
snippet: China's growing energy needs are making the idea of a trans-Pacific market for Canadian oil increasingly attractive.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Ever since an oil well near Leduc, Alberta, made Canada a significant oil producer in 1947, the energy export business here has relied almost entirely on the United States.

abstract: An OPEC official predicts a return to prewar levels by the end of 2012, but others are not as optimistic.
snippet: An OPEC official predicts a return to prewar levels by the end of 2012, but others are not as optimistic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Representatives of OPEC and Libya gave different outlooks Tuesday about how long it might take Libya to restore its oil production to prewar levels.

abstract: Marcus Mabry, an editor with the International Herald Tribune, speaks with Shokri Ghanem, the former chairman of Libya’s state-run oil company.
snippet: Marcus Mabry, an editor with the International Herald Tribune, speaks with Shokri Ghanem, the former chairman of Libya’s state-run oil company.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Mabry, an editor with the International Herald Tribune, speaks with Shokri Ghanem, the former chairman of Libya’s state-run oil company.

snippet: The following is a transcript of the Republican presidential debate in Las Vegas, Nev.
lead_paragraph: The following is a transcript of the Western Republican Leadership Conference (WRLC)/CNN Republican presidential debate in Las Vegas, Nev., as provided by Federal News Service.

abstract: Unconventional fossil fuels extracted by new technologies should shift geopolitical and economic calculations around the world in the coming decades.
snippet: Unconventional fossil fuels extracted by new technologies should shift geopolitical and economic calculations around the world in the coming decades.
lead_paragraph: GOLDA MEIR, the former prime minister of Israel, used to tell a joke about how Moses must have made a wrong turn in the desert: “He dragged us 40 years through the desert to bring us to the one place in the Middle East where there was no oil.’ ”

abstract: Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, a k a Carlos the Jackal, is to stand trial on Monday for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s.
snippet: Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, a k a Carlos the Jackal, is to stand trial on Monday for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He has lost much of his hair and, after a 10-day prison hunger strike last month, a bit of his signature paunch. But as he prepares to stand trial on Monday for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s, Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, better known as Carlos the Jackal, seems to have lost little of his bravado.

abstract: Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, a k a Carlos the Jackal, began his trial on Monday for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s.
snippet: Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, a k a Carlos the Jackal, began his trial on Monday for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He has lost much of his hair and, after a 10-day prison hunger strike last month, a bit of his signature paunch. But as his trial for a series of bombings he is accused of orchestrating in the early 1980s began on Monday, Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, better known as Carlos the Jackal, seemed to have lost little of his bravado.

abstract: Mr. Owen was an influential diplomat who helped institutionalize global economic summitry in the 1970s and was considered an intellectual framer of the Trilateral Commission.
snippet: Mr. Owen was an influential diplomat who helped institutionalize global economic summitry in the 1970s and was considered an intellectual framer of the Trilateral Commission.
lead_paragraph: Henry D. Owen, an influential diplomat who helped institutionalize global economic summitry in the 1970s and who was considered an intellectual framer of the elite round table known as the Trilateral Commission, died on Nov. 5 in Washington. He was 91.

abstract: An interview with Carlos Pascual, the United States' special envoy and coordinator for international energy affairs.
snippet: An interview with Carlos Pascual, the United States' special envoy and coordinator for international energy affairs.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Pascual is the United States’ special envoy and coordinator for international energy affairs. He advises Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on energy issues and is responsible for defending American national and commercial energy interests worldwide. From 2009 to 2011, he was the U.S. ambassador to Mexico. He resigned as envoy in May after several frank comments about the Mexican military were revealed by WikiLeaks, angering President Felipe Calderón of Mexico. From 2003 to 2009, Mr. Pascual was director of the foreign policy studies program at the Brookings Institution, a leading Washington research group.

abstract: Fast-growing exports of coal from rich countries to China show the limits of domestic greenhouse-gas policy.
snippet: Fast-growing exports of coal from rich countries to China show the limits of domestic greenhouse-gas policy.
lead_paragraph: Nov. 19, 10:59 a.m. | Updated

abstract: The company’s $2.4 billion plan to buy Pringles from Procter & Gamble has run into accounting and other issues.
snippet: The company’s $2.4 billion plan to buy Pringles from Procter & Gamble has run into accounting and other issues.
lead_paragraph: Things aren’t getting any better for the snack food maker Diamond Foods. A month ago, it delayed its $2.4 billion plan to buy Pringles from Procter & Gamble in order to look into accounting concerns. Now, the company is burying news about the inquiry and increasing payments to a couple of directors who are walnut growers. These and other inconsistencies don’t seem to augur well for the investigation, or its deal with Procter & Gamble.

abstract: A legacy deal for Obama on gas mileage will make a significant contribution to America’s energy, environmental, health and national security agendas.
snippet: A legacy deal for Obama on gas mileage will make a significant contribution to America’s energy, environmental, health and national security agendas.
lead_paragraph: IN many ways, President Obama has been a disappointment on energy and the environment. He has been completely missing in action on the climate debate. His decision to block his own Environmental Protection Agency from setting new rules to cut smog levels was disappointing. And, while I believe in using the balance sheet of the U.S. government to spur clean-tech research and start-ups, Solyndra was a case of embarrassing excess — precisely what happens when you rely too much on government push not consumer pull, spurred by price and regulatory signals.

abstract: By settling its dispute with MBIA, Morgan Stanley can increase regulatory capital and begin 2012 on more solid footing.
snippet: By settling its dispute with MBIA, Morgan Stanley can increase regulatory capital and begin 2012 on more solid footing.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley’s settlement with the bond insurer MBIA leaves behind another big chunk of the financial crisis. At $1.8 billion, it doesn’t come cheap for James Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive. But it puts Mr. Gorman’s company on the right track by increasing regulatory capital and tidying up a very messy second year for him.

abstract: A move by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase its production target should have little lasting effect on oil prices.
snippet: A move by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase its production target should have little lasting effect on oil prices.
lead_paragraph: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on Wednesday to increase its production target for the first time in three years, a move that appeared to signal that Saudi Arabia and Iran had put aside their recent differences on oil policy, at least temporarily.

abstract: The N.C.A.A. is a walking, talking antitrust violation.
snippet: The N.C.A.A. is a walking, talking antitrust violation.
lead_paragraph: Twice a year in Vienna, the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gather to decide on the short-term direction of oil prices. Sometimes, O.P.E.C. agrees to cut back on oil production, pushing up the price of oil. Other times, it decides to boost production. Always, the goal is to fix the price of oil, rather than allow it to be set by the competitive marketplace. Indeed, collusion and price-fixing are the main reasons cartels exist — and why they are illegal in America.

abstract: Tehran is loudly declaring that it is willing to shut down the Strait of Hormuz in the event of more pressure from the West.
snippet: Tehran is loudly declaring that it is willing to shut down the Strait of Hormuz in the event of more pressure from the West.
lead_paragraph: The past two weeks have seen a dramatic escalation in Iran’s war of words with the West.

abstract: Buying less Iranian oil would further tighten the economic vise on an increasingly defiant nation that announced plans for a new round of naval drills in the Strait of Hormuz.
snippet: Buying less Iranian oil would further tighten the economic vise on an increasingly defiant nation that announced plans for a new round of naval drills in the Strait of Hormuz.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Under growing pressure from the United States, some of Asia’s largest economies are reluctantly looking for options to reduce the amount of oil they buy from Iran, a move that would further tighten the economic vise on an increasingly defiant nation that announced plans for a new round of naval drills in the Strait of Hormuz.

abstract: A bid to end gasoline subsidies in oil-rich Nigeria highlights the evils of the "resource curse."
snippet: A bid to end gasoline subsidies in oil-rich Nigeria highlights the evils of the "resource curse."
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 1 Nigerians awoke to find that the price of gasoline had gone from just under $2 a gallon to almost $4 a gallon. Since the beginning of this week, tens of thousands of angry protesters have taken to the streets all over the country; several are dead. Apart from nationwide protests, the country faces continuing sectarian violence. Many fear Nigeria is on the precipice of total collapse.

abstract: Saudi Arabia and its Arab neighbors have said they will fill any gap in energy supplies for countries that yield to pressure from Washington to curtail purchases of Iranian crude.
snippet: Saudi Arabia and its Arab neighbors have said they will fill any gap in energy supplies for countries that yield to pressure from Washington to curtail purchases of Iranian crude.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pressure on Iran mounted on Thursday, with the United States saying it was determined to isolate the country’s central bank, and three of Iran’s largest oil customers — Japan, South Korea and China — getting assurances that Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf producers would help make up any gap in supplies if they curtailed oil purchases from Iran.

abstract: Factory-rated output is not woods-of-Maine output, the author discovers as he adds up the kilowatt hours.
snippet: Factory-rated output is not woods-of-Maine output, the author discovers as he adds up the kilowatt hours.
lead_paragraph: For our year living in the woods of Maine, I wanted a place where I could see and hear wildlife. Someplace both quiet and remote.

abstract: The promise by Saudi Arabia to keep the taps open, falling between President Obama signing new sanctions aimed at Iran and Monday’s EU meeting on banning Iranian imports, was not a coincidence. But it could backfire or even benefit Tehran.
snippet: The promise by Saudi Arabia to keep the taps open, falling between President Obama signing new sanctions aimed at Iran and Monday’s EU meeting on banning Iranian imports, was not a coincidence. But it could backfire or even benefit Tehran.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Can Saudi Arabia live up to a promise to fill the oil-supply gap if new U.S. and European sanctions succeed in locking down Iran’s exports of crude?

abstract: Saudi Arabia’s oil minister says he sees a purpose for renewable energy in his country and he warns that climate change is indeed a pressing problem.
snippet: Saudi Arabia’s oil minister says he sees a purpose for renewable energy in his country and he warns that climate change is indeed a pressing problem.
lead_paragraph: When you think of proponents of green energy, the Saudi oil minister may not be the first person who comes to mind. But in a speech on Monday in London, Ali al-Naimi, the minister from OPEC’s leading member nation, had a lot to say about renewable energy and global warming.

abstract: Canada moves on to China after getting the cold shoulder from the United States.
snippet: Canada moves on to China after getting the cold shoulder from the United States.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Stephen Harper, the prime minister of Canada, traveled to China for a week of high-level meetings.  He brought with him a handful of his cabinet ministers, including Joe Oliver, his tough-talking minister of natural resources who, until recently, had been withering in his scorn for the opponents of the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which President Obama rejected a few weeks ago.  The pipeline, of course, was intended to transport vast oil reserves in Alberta to the American refineries on the Gulf of Mexico.

abstract: Building the oil pipeline is not going to lead to apocalypse.
snippet: Building the oil pipeline is not going to lead to apocalypse.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the question on the table today: Can a person support the Keystone XL oil pipeline and still believe that global warming poses a serious threat?

abstract: Besieged by sanctions over its nuclear program, Iran warned its six largest European buyers that they risked immediate cutoffs in their Iranian oil imports.
snippet: Besieged by sanctions over its nuclear program, Iran warned its six largest European buyers that they risked immediate cutoffs in their Iranian oil imports.
lead_paragraph: Besieged by international sanctions over the Iranian nuclear program including a planned oil embargo by Europe, Iran warned six European buyers on Wednesday that it might strike first by immediately cutting them off from Iranian oil.

abstract: The CME Group announced on Tuesday that it would increase its holdings in the Dubai Mercantile Exchange, delving deeper into a Middle Eastern oil trading business it helped create.
snippet: The CME Group announced on Tuesday that it would increase its holdings in the Dubai Mercantile Exchange, delving deeper into a Middle Eastern oil trading business it helped create.
lead_paragraph: The CME Group announced on Tuesday that it would increase its stake in the Dubai Mercantile Exchange, delving deeper into a Middle Eastern oil trading business it helped create.

abstract: Something in the inbox recently reopened the debate over who is responsible for higher oil prices.
snippet: Something in the inbox recently reopened the debate over who is responsible for higher oil prices.
lead_paragraph: AN e-mail came in the other day with a subject line that I couldn’t ignore. It was from the oil economist Phil Verleger, and it read: “Should the United States join OPEC?” That I had to open.

abstract: Cognitive dissonance persists on the presidential campaign trail and in Congress, but some energy statistics are telling.
snippet: Cognitive dissonance persists on the presidential campaign trail and in Congress, but some energy statistics are telling.
lead_paragraph: On the day after Super Tuesday, the federal Energy Information Administration came out with a striking fact: in 2011, the United States, for the first time since 1949, exported more petroleum products than it imported.

abstract: How much are Americans freaked out by the prospect of paying $4 a gallon at the pump? A whole lot ... and not at all.
snippet: How much are Americans freaked out by the prospect of paying $4 a gallon at the pump? A whole lot ... and not at all.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of carless New Yorkers, I am generally confused by bursts of populist outrage over high gas prices. But I have always assumed that the anger is genuine — that hard-working Americans, who already spend a lot on gas, are thrown into turmoil when they have to spend even more. After all, 63 percent of Americans insist that these price increases have caused them some financial hardship.

abstract: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve should be preserved to address an actual emergency rather than chronic weakness.
snippet: The Strategic Petroleum Reserve should be preserved to address an actual emergency rather than chronic weakness.
lead_paragraph: AS oil and gasoline prices rise, political pressure to tap the roughly 700 million barrels in the national Strategic Petroleum Reserve is building, including among some in Congress. The global oil market is fundamentally strained and suffering from an array of unwelcome but unremarkable problems. Yet the oil reserve is neither designed nor well equipped to address these chronic weaknesses. Instead it should be preserved to address an emergency disruption in supply.

abstract: An energy revival in the United States has upended expectations and calculations about the country’s future, including its foreign policy and economy.
snippet: An energy revival in the United States has upended expectations and calculations about the country’s future, including its foreign policy and economy.
lead_paragraph: THE reversal of fortune in America’s energy supplies in recent years holds the promise of abundant and cheaper fuel, and it could have profound effects on what people drive, domestic manufacturing and America’s foreign policy.

abstract: The 2012 Ford Focus Electric, the first all-electric car from a Detroit automaker in the 21st century, has the road manners of a gasoline car and looks nearly identical to the regular Focus.
snippet: The 2012 Ford Focus Electric, the first all-electric car from a Detroit automaker in the 21st century, has the road manners of a gasoline car and looks nearly identical to the regular Focus.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif.

abstract: A 12 percent decline in the first three months of the year is at odds with Iran’s assessment that there has been no significant change in output over the past year.
snippet: A 12 percent decline in the first three months of the year is at odds with Iran’s assessment that there has been no significant change in output over the past year.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian oil production, the backbone of the Islamic republic’s economy, fell by 12 percent in the first three months of the year and is likely to fall even more, industry experts say, as sanctions make it increasingly hard for the country to find markets for its crude.

abstract: A decline in Iranian oil demand from reliable customers including India, after pressure from Obama administration.
snippet: A decline in Iranian oil demand from reliable customers including India, after pressure from Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: Iranian oil production, “the backbone of the Islamic republic’s economy,” fell by 12 percent in the first three months of the year and “is likely to fall even more, industry experts say, as sanctions make it increasingly hard for the country to find markets for its crude,” Thomas Erdrink writes in The New York Times.

abstract: The cost of a gallon of gasoline is dropping, especially on the East Coast, because of growing oil supplies and a decline in global crude oil prices.
snippet: The cost of a gallon of gasoline is dropping, especially on the East Coast, because of growing oil supplies and a decline in global crude oil prices.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As the Memorial Day weekend and the summer driving season approach, gasoline prices are easing. But most drivers will find prices only modestly lower than a year ago.

abstract: Analysts say an Iraqi boom should cushion oil markets from price spikes and offer relief for the West as it tightens sanctions on Iran.
snippet: Analysts say an Iraqi boom should cushion oil markets from price spikes and offer relief for the West as it tightens sanctions on Iran.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Despite sectarian bombings and political gridlock, Iraq’s crude oil production is soaring, providing a singular bright spot for the nation’s future and relief for global oil markets as the West tightens sanctions on Iranian exports.

abstract: The United States is now a much more significant energy producer than the last time we elected a president.
snippet: The United States is now a much more significant energy producer than the last time we elected a president.
lead_paragraph: Washington

abstract: Prices for a range of goods, including cotton, copper and gasoline, have fallen in recent weeks, a sign of faltering demand.
snippet: Prices for a range of goods, including cotton, copper and gasoline, have fallen in recent weeks, a sign of faltering demand.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Mark Juull, a construction contractor for public and residential housing, has something to be thankful for in this sluggish economy: With global commodity prices falling, he’s saving $200 a week on fuel for his three trucks and finding deals on aluminum, lumber and roof shingles, which are typically made from petroleum.

abstract: The decision leaves Saudi Arabia to decide on its own whether to influence prices by adjusting output before the next OPEC meeting in December.
snippet: The decision leaves Saudi Arabia to decide on its own whether to influence prices by adjusting output before the next OPEC meeting in December.
lead_paragraph: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries left unchanged a ceiling for oil production at a meeting in Vienna on Thursday, despite signs of a slowdown in the global economy and slumping oil prices.

abstract: We are still reaping the consequences of the party’s failure to respond coherently to the economic dislocation of the 1970s and ’80s.
snippet: We are still reaping the consequences of the party’s failure to respond coherently to the economic dislocation of the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: For more than four decades most Americans identified the Democratic Party with a social contract and safety net, equality of justice and opportunity, and progressive — yes, even liberal — causes. Sometime in the last 30 years the party of progress and change — Emerson’s party of hope — became the party of reactionary liberalism.

abstract: At least 19 people were killed in the attacks, which led to retaliation by Christian youths who dragged Muslims from cars and killed them, officials and witnesses said.
snippet: At least 19 people were killed in the attacks, which led to retaliation by Christian youths who dragged Muslims from cars and killed them, officials and witnesses said.
lead_paragraph: ZARIA, Nigeria (Reuters) — Suicide car bombers attacked three churches in a northern Nigerian state on Sunday, killing at least 19 people and wounding dozens, and setting off retaliatory attacks by Christian youths who dragged Muslims from cars and killed them, officials and witnesses said.

abstract: A new report points to an extended era of expanding oil production capacity.
snippet: A new report points to an extended era of expanding oil production capacity.
lead_paragraph: [Please be sure to read this followup post, as well: “Oil’s Long Goodbye and a Species’ Quest for Self Control.“]

abstract: As expected, the Army Corps of Engineers approved a permit for a leg passing through Texas.
snippet: As expected, the Army Corps of Engineers approved a permit for a leg passing through Texas.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, moving swiftly on the president’s promise to expedite the southernmost portion of the disputed Keystone XL pipeline, has granted construction permits for part of the route passing through Texas, officials said on Tuesday.

abstract: As its oil inventory grows because of tough sanctions, Iran has taken to repainting and renaming its tankers, concealing their origins in a bid to find buyers.
snippet: As its oil inventory grows because of tough sanctions, Iran has taken to repainting and renaming its tankers, concealing their origins in a bid to find buyers.
lead_paragraph: BANDAR ABBAS, Iran — The hulking tanker Neptune was floating aimlessly this week in the warm waters of the Persian Gulf, a fresh coat of black paint barely concealing its true identity as an Iranian ship loaded with hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil that no one is willing to buy.

abstract: Imports of oil from the kingdom have grown by more than 20 percent this year, leaving the United States vulnerable to tensions in the Persian Gulf.
snippet: Imports of oil from the kingdom have grown by more than 20 percent this year, leaving the United States vulnerable to tensions in the Persian Gulf.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The United States is increasing its dependence on oil from Saudi Arabia, raising its imports from the kingdom by more than 20 percent this year, even as fears of military conflict in the tinderbox Persian Gulf region grow.

abstract: Tony Hayward, the chief of BP who was accused of insensitivity and incompetence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill of 2010, is back in the oil business and seeking redemption.
snippet: Tony Hayward, the chief of BP who was accused of insensitivity and incompetence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill of 2010, is back in the oil business and seeking redemption.
